Description: OPERA LAFAYETTE, DU MONDE: EXPLORING OPERA AT THE  INTERSECTION OF EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY COLONIALISM AND INDEPENDENCE [OPERA LAFAYETTE HAS DEVELOPED A NETWORK OF LEADING SCHOLARS AND ARTIST-SCHOLARS AT THE HEART OF THE EARLY MUSIC MOVEMENT TO CONVEY THE CULTURAL HISTORY OF THESE WORKS IN ACCESSIBLE, PUBLIC HUMANITIES-ORIENTED FORUMS. OUR 2021-2022 PRODUCTIONS WILL BE ILLUMINED BY AN ARRAY OF SYMPOSIA, SCHOLARLY PANELS, PRE- AND POST-PERFORMANCE LECTURES, EXPERTLY RESEARCHED PROGRAM MATERIALS, AND AN ONGOING DOCUMENTARY FILM PROJECT.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE RECOVERY AND REPRODUCTION OF THREE 18TH CENTURY FRENCH OPERAS AT OPERA LAFAYETTE IN WASHINGTON D.C.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: OL WILL CREATE PROGRAMMING TO ENCOURAGE HUMANISTIC INTERPRETATION OF EARLY MUSIC THROUGH LECTURE VIDEOS, SCHOLARLY LEARNING GUIDES, AND MODERATED DISCUSSION FORUMS EMPHASIZING MUSICOLOGY AND SOCIAL AND POLITICAL HISTORY. OL WILL ALSO CREATE ADVANCED-LEVEL SYMPOSIA AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AROUND CONTEMPORARY AND HISTORICAL LAND RIGHTS AND WATER ISSUES (SILVAIN), ROYAL PATRONAGE AND THE POLITICS OF THE FRENCH ENLIGHTENMENT (MARIE ANTOINETTE), AND THE COMPLEX HISTORY OF MUSIC IN THE FRENCH CARIBBEAN (KOUROU). THEY ALSO PLAN TO PRODUCE A SHORT DOCUMENTARY FILM ON LEONORE/FIDELIO AND L'AMOUR CONJUGAL.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: OL'S PROPOSED ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY FOR AUDIENCES TO REEXAMINE HISTORICAL PIECES ALONGSIDE CONTEMPORARY ISSUES. OL WILL RETAIN THREE POSITIONS AND CREATE 12 NEW CONTRACTOR POSITIONS TO CREATE THE INTERPRETIVE AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR THE PIECES.   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: NATIONAL AUDIENCES AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN WASHINGTON, D.C. AND NEW YORK CITY WILL BENEFIT FROM OL'S HYBRID PROGRAMMING. OL'S ONLINE PRESENCE AND PLANS TO CURATE PROGRAMMING WITH HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY RELEVANCE WILL HELP OL REACH BEYOND THE EARLY MUSIC AUDIENCE TO INFLUENCE HUMANITIES BROADLY.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS FOR CONTRACTUAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.]

"BRIDGING COMMUNITIES: THE MOVING IMAGE" [AMIA SEEKS $50K FROM THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT OF THE HUMANITIES TO SUPPORT THE PRODUCTION OF ISSUES 22.1/22.2 AND 23.1 OF ITS PRINT JOURNAL, THE MOVING IMAGE, A HYBRID JOURNAL THAT ALIGNS WITH SEVERAL PROFESSIONS AND COMMUNITIES OF THINKERS, SCHOLARS AND PRACTITIONERS INTERESTED IN ARCHIVAL ISSUES AND MATERIALS. THIS JOURNAL IS UNIQUE IN THAT IT PROVIDES A PLATFORM FOR WRITERS WHO ARE PRACTITIONERS IN THE FIELD OF MOVING IMAGE ARCHIVES AND THEREFORE NOT TYPICALLY INCLUDED IN ACADEMIC JOURNALS, AND ITS ABILITY TO BRIDGE AND FOSTER MEANINGFUL COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MULTIPLE COMMUNITIES WORKING IN FILM, ARCHIVES AND PRESERVATION OFFERS A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE ADVANCEMENT OF THE PUBLIC HUMANITIES.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PUBLISH TWO EDITIONS OF THE ASSOCIATION OF MOVING IMAGE ARCHIVISTS' (AMIA) HYBRID JOURNAL THE MOVING IMAGE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: AMIA WILL PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE TWO EDITIONS OF THE JOURNAL PUBLICATION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE MOVING IMAGE JOURNAL WILL PROVIDE A PLATFORM FOR ARTISTS, PRODUCERS, SCHOLARS, AND INTERPRETERS OF VISUAL CULTURE TO ENGAGE FILM AND MOVING IMAGE STUDY. AMIA WILL RETAIN TWO FULL-TIME STAFF MEMBERS AND TWO EDITORS TO PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE THE TWO EDITIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ARTISTS, PRODUCERS, SCHOLARS, AND INTERPRETERS OF VISUAL CULTURE WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PUBLICATION. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

SUSTAINING AND EXPANDING PUBLIC HUMANITIES PROGRAMS AT TWO OF HAWAII?S ROYAL PALACES: ON-SITE, DIGITAL AND HYBRID [THE DAUGHTERS OF HAWAII?S HUMANITIES MISSION IS TO SERVE AS AN AUTHENTIC LENS FOR LEARNING ABOUT AND IMMERSION IN THE CULTURES OF INDIGENOUS NATIVE HAWAIIANS AND THE KINGDOM OF HAWAII. OUR PROJECT ADVANCES CRITICAL INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS AT TWO OF HAWAII?S ROYAL PALACES USING TODAY?S TECHNOLOGY. PALACE TOURS AND EXHIBITS WILL HIGHLIGHT THE STRENGTHS, ACHIEVEMENTS, AND UNTOLD STORIES OF HAWAII?S POWERFUL QUEENS AND PRINCESSES, WHO EMBRACED WESTERN SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND DIPLOMACY, TO TRANSFORM SOCIAL, ECONOMIC AND EDUCATION CONDITIONS FOR THEIR PEOPLE, UNHEARD OF IN THE 1850S. OUR FOCUS RECOGNIZES THEIR VISIONARY CONTRIBUTIONS THAT LIVE ON IN PRESENT-DAY HAWAII. OTHER PROGRAM ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INTERACTIVE CLASSES, ANNUAL COMMUNITY FESTIVALS, PUBLIC FORUMS, AND INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS WITH CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS AND SCHOLARS. IN-PERSON, VIRTUAL AND HYBRID ACTIVITIES WILL OFFER PARTICIPANTS DIRECT EXPERIENCES IN THE HERITAGE, ARTS AND CULTURE OF HAWAII, ITS PAST, AND ITS DIVERSITY.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP AN INTERPRETIVE TOUR AND SPECIAL EXHIBIT HIGHLIGHTING HAWAII?S QUEENS AND PRINCESSES AT TWO ROYAL PALACES IN THE DAUGHTERS OF HAWAII?S STEWARDSHIP.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE DAUGHTERS WILL REINTERPRET TOURS AND EXHIBITS TO HIGHLIGHT THE UNTOLD STORIES OF HAWAII?S QUEENS AND PRINCESSES. THE DAUGHTERS WILL ALSO RECRUIT GUEST LECTURERS AND CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS TO CONDUCT INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS AND TALK STORY SESSIONS. LASTLY, THE DAUGHTERS WILL COORDINATE HYBRID COMMUNITY CULTURAL FESTIVALS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE EXHIBIT AND PROGRAMMING WILL HELP PRESERVE AND INTERPRET INDIGENOUS HAWAIIAN HISTORY AND CULTURE. THE NEW QUEENS EXHIBIT WILL ALSO PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO STUDY WOMEN?S CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE KINGDOM OF HAWAII. THE DAUGHTERS WILL RETAIN THREE STAFF MEMBERS TO CONDUCT THE ACTIVITIES FOR THE EXHIBIT.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL AUDIENCES, LOCAL COMMUNITIES, TOURISTS, AND SCHOLARS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE QUEENS EXHIBIT.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

ARP RELIEF: MEXICAN MODERNISM EXHIBITION AND HUMANITIES POSITIONS [PHILBROOK MUSEUM OF ART WILL DEVELOP AND PRESENT THE TRAVELING EXHIBITION "FRIDA KAHLO, DIEGO RIVERA, AND MID-CENTURY MEXICAN MODERNISM" IN JUNE-SEPTEMBER 2022.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP AND PRESENT AN EXHIBITION OF MEXICAN MODERNIST ART AT THE PHILBROOK MUSEUM OF ART IN TULSA, OK.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PHILBROOK WILL DEVELOP THE EXHIBITION FRIDA KAHLO, DIEGO RIVERA, AND MID-CENTURY MEXICAN MODERNISM. THE EXHIBIT WILL CONSIST OF DOCUMENTARY PHOTOGRAPHS, A DOZEN OUTFITS (AND JEWELRY) RECONSTRUCTED TO CLOSELY REPLICATE KAHLO?S ATTIRE, AND A GARDEN ON PHILBROOK?S GROUNDS INSPIRED BY KAHLO?S OWN GARDEN AT HER HOME, CASA AZUL. PHILBROOK WILL ALSO DEVELOP IN-GALLERY INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS INCLUDING TEXT PANELS ABOUT THEMES OF NATIONAL IDENTITY, PERSONA IDENTITY, AND RESILIENCE; INDIVIDUAL LABELS ADDRESSING THE HISTORICAL CONTEXT OF SELECT WORKS; AND FILM FOOTAGE OF THE ARTISTS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PHILBROOK?S PROPOSED EXHIBIT AND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING WILL ENGAGE THE HISPANIC/LATINX COMMUNITY IN TULSA, OKLAHOMA?THE LARGEST MINORITY POPULATION IN THE CITY WHERE THE MUSEUM IS LOCATED?CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUTREACH AND PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE MUSEUM AND THE COMMUNITY.&NBSP;  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO HELP RETAIN EIGHT FULL-TIME HUMANITIES POSITIONS, RESTORE ONE PREVIOUSLY ELIMINATED FULL TIME POSITION, AND RETAIN THREE ADDITIONAL FULL-TIME AND SEVERAL PART-TIME POSITIONS IN SUPPORT OF THIS HUMANITIES PROJECT  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL AUDIENCES, MUSEUM VISITORS, AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THE EXHIBIT.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

RAILS TO FREEDOM: NEW RESEARCH AND INTERPRETATION ON THE B&O RAILROAD'S ROLE IN THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD [THE B&O RAILROAD MUSEUM HAS DEFINITIVELY DOCUMENTED THAT FREEDOM SEEKERS USED THE BALTIMORE AND OHIO RAILROAD AS PART OF THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD. THE PURPOSE OF THE REQUESTED FUNDING IS TO FINISH OUR PROJECT, STARTED IN JANUARY 2020, ON THIS NEWLY DOCUMENTED HISTORY WITH PUBLIC INTERPRETATION AND EXHIBITION IN THE HISTORIC PASSENGER DEPOT AT MT. CLARE STATION, A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK IN BALTIMORE. THE FUNDING WILL ADDITIONALLY ASSURE THE MUSEUM IS NOT FORCED TO FURLOUGH STAFF AS A RESULT OF THE CONTINUED FINANCIAL IMPACT OF THE COVID PANDEMIC ON THE MUSEUM'S REVENUE AND ATTENDANCE. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE MUSEUM'S FINANCIAL RECOVERY FROM COVID AND FUTURE SUSTAINABILITY.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN RAILROAD ORAL ARCHIVES PROJECT AT THE B&O RAILROAD MUSEUM IN BALTIMORE.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE B&O RAILROAD MUSEUM WILL UNDERTAKE AN ORAL HISTORY PROJECT TO INTERPRET AND SHARE UNTOLD HISTORIES OF THE RAILWAY'S ROLE IN THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD EFFORTS. AS A PART OF THE PROJECT, B&O WILL TRANSFORM THE MT. CLARE PASSENGER DEPOT INTO EXHIBITION SPACE; EXPAND SCHOOL PROGRAMS THROUGH VIRTUAL TOURS, FIELDTRIPS, AND TRAVELING PROGRAMS; AND ADAPT A FREE SUMMER PROGRAM TO INCLUDE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD HISTORY. THE MUSEUM WILL RECRUIT THREE GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS FROM MORGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, A HISTORICALLY BLACK UNIVERSITY, TO HELP DEVELOP THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD PROJECT.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE AFRICAN AMERICAN RAILROAD ORAL ARCHIVES PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VISITORS WITH AN IMMERSIVE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE. THE PROJECT SHOULD HELP VISITORS BETTER UNDERSTAND THE EXPERIENCE OF THE FREEDOM SEEKERS THAT PASSED THROUGH THE SITE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO THE FINANCIAL RECOVERY FROM COVID AND FUTURE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE MUSEUM. MOREOVER, THE INTENTIONAL RECRUITMENT OF STUDENTS FROM A MAJOR HBCU IN THE BALTIMORE AREA WILL INCREASE THE REPRESENTATION OF AFRICAN AMERICANS IN B&O PROGRAMS AND PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH PAID OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN. B&O WILL RETAIN EIGHT CURRENT STAFF MEMBERS AND RECRUIT THREE-PART TIME GRADUATE STUDENTS TO HELP DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT.   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE GENERAL PUBLIC, MUSEUM VISITORS, RESEARCHERS, STAFF, AND STUDENT INTERNS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PROJECT'S INTERPRETATION OF UNDERGROUND RAILROAD HISTORY, PARTICULARLY THE ROLE OF B&O RAILROAD'S ROLE IN THE JOURNEY TO FREEDOM.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

ENHANCING COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITIONS AT THE MUSEUM [THE MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION RESPECTFULLY REQUESTS A NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE HUMANITIES GRANT TO SUPPORT A NEW POSITION, DIRECTOR OF COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITIONS, AND THE DEVELOPMENT AND PILOTING OF A TRAVELING EXHIBITION SERIES. THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT GOALS IN THE STRATEGIC PLAN (2019-2026) BY INCREASING AWARENESS OF THE MUSEUM?S COLLECTION, INTERPRETATIVE RESOURCES, AND UNIQUE PEDAGOGY LEADING UP TO THE NATION'S SEMIQUINCENTENNIAL IN 2026 AND EXPEDITE THE MUSEUM'S RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM DEFERRED PLANS TO FILL THE POSITION LAST SPRING AS PART OF COST-SAVING MEASURES IMPLEMENTED TO OFFSET ANTICIPATED LOSSES TO EARNED AND CONTRIBUTED REVENUE BECAUSE OF THE PANDEMIC.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP PROGRAMMING AT THE MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION MARKING THE 250TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE MUSEUM WILL RESEARCH, DEVELOP, AND IMPLEMENT A TRAVEL EXHIBITION FEATURING DON TROIANI, A NATIONALLY KNOWN ARTIST WHOSE DRAMATIC AND RESEARCH-BASED WORK CAPTURES THE DIVERSE PEOPLE AND COMPLEX EVENTS OF THE REVOLUTION. ?LIBERTY: DON TROIANI?S PAINTINGS OF THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR? WILL BRING TOGETHER NEARLY 40 OF TROIANI'S ORIGINAL REVOLUTIONARY WAR PAINTINGS AND PAIR THEM WITH DOZENS OF ARTIFACTS FROM HIS PERSONAL COLLECTION AND THE COLLECTIONS OF OTHER LENDERS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE MUSEUM?S PLANNED TRAVELING EXHIBITION WILL INCREASE UNDERSTANDING AND INTERPRETATION OF THE NATION?S EARLY HISTORY AND MAKE HUMANITIES ACCESSIBLE TO PUBLIC AUDIENCES WHILE GENERATING FUNDS TO SUPPORT FUTURE PROGRAMS AT THE MUSEUM. FUNDING WILL ENABLE THE MUSEUM TO RETAIN FOUR POSITIONS, INCLUDING THE RECENTLY CREATED POST OF DIRECTOR OF COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITIONS, TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: MUSEUM PATRONS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE MUSEUM?S INTERPRETATION OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NATION.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

VIETNAM: THE REAL WAR AND THE THINGS THEY CARRIED [THIS SERIES OF HUMANITIES PROGRAMS ASKS, ?HOW DO WE TELL THE TRUTH IN WAR?? THE EXPERIENCE CENTERS ON AN EXHIBITION OF ASSOCIATED PRESS PHOTOGRAPHS THAT DOCUMENTED AND CHANGED HISTORY. DUMA WILL PARTNER WITH THE GROUT MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND SCIENCE AND THE UNIVERSITY OF DUBUQUE TO TRAIN STUDENT VETERANS TO RECORD AND SHARE THE ORAL HISTORIES OF VIETNAM VETERANS. THE STUDENTS WILL CREATE AN EXHIBITION INSPIRED BY THEIR EXPERIENCES. MUSEUM GUESTS WILL ALSO EXPLORE AN INSTALLATION OF ARTIFACTS INSPIRED BY THE ACCLAIMED BOOK THE THINGS THEY CARRIED. CONCURRENT EXHIBITIONS ADD PERSPECTIVES INCLUDING THE WAR PHOTOGRAPHY OF DUBUQUE JOURNALIST BOB WOODWARD AND RON TESTA, AN OFFICIAL NAVY PHOTOGRAPHER. LECTURES, FILM SCREENINGS AND BOOK DISCUSSIONS WILL EXPAND GUESTS UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF ARTISTS IN TELLING THE STORY. PLANS INCLUDE CONVERSATIONS WITH TIM O?BRIEN AND ART HISTORIAN TERI VAN DORSTON AND A SCREENING OF SPIKE LEE?S DA 5 BLOODS.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN ORAL HISTORY EXHIBITION ON THE VIETNAM WAR AT THE DUBUQUE MUSEUM OF ART IN&NBSP;DUBUQUE, IOWA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DUMA WILL PARTNER WITH THE GROUT MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND SCIENCE AND THE UNIVERSITY OF DUBUQUE TO TRAIN STUDENT VETERANS TO INTERVIEW VIETNAM VETERANS FROM THE VETERANS FREEDOM CENTER AND TO INTERPRET THOSE ORAL HISTORIES FOR MUSEUM GUESTS. THE STUDENT VETERANS WILL ALSO CURATE AN EXHIBITION IN THE UNIVERSITY?S ART GALLERIES INSPIRED THEIR EXPERIENCES. DUMA WILL ALSO COLLABORATE WITH THE DUBUQUE COMMUNITY SCHOOLS TO CREATE GUIDED TOURS FOR SOCIAL STUDIES AND PHOTOGRAPHY CLASSES. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE CARNEGIE-STOUT PUBLIC LIBRARY, DUMA WILL PRODUCE SCHOLARLY LECTURES FEATURING ART HISTORIAN TERI VAN DORSTON AND AUTHOR AND FILMMAKER CONVERSATIONS WITH TIM O?BRIEN AND AARON MATTHEWS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS COMMUNITY-WIDE SERIES OF PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE A NEW GENERATION OF AUDIENCES IN DIALOGUE?ONLINE AND IN-PERSON?ABOUT A HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT EVENT IN AMERICAN HISTORY. LECTURES, FILM SCREENINGS AND BOOK DISCUSSIONS WILL EXPAND GUESTS UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF ARTISTS IN TELLING THE STORY. THE PARTNERSHIPS AT THE CENTER OF VIETNAM: THE REAL WAR WILL EXTEND DUMA?S REACH INTO VETERANS? CENTERS, LIBRARIES, UNIVERSITY CAMPUSES, LOCAL NEWSPAPERS AND THEATERS. VIETNAM: THE REAL WAR WILL HELP DUMA RETAIN TEN POSITIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL AUDIENCES, LOCAL COMMUNITIES, VISITORS, LOCAL STUDENTS, MUSEUM STAFF, VETERANS AND HISTORIANS WILL BENEFIT FROM DUMA?S PROGRAMS AND PARTNERSHIPS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

PROVIDING PUBLIC HISTORY PROGRAMS FOR ADULTS AND YOUTH IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA [IN 2020, OUR ADULT AND YOUTH PUBLIC PROGRAMMING SHIFTED FROM IN-PERSON TO VIRTUAL IN ORDER TO COMPLY WITH PUBLIC HEALTH GUIDELINES WHILE ALSO FULFILLING OUR MISSION. NOW THAT COVID-RELATED RESTRICTIONS ARE EASING, WE WILL RESTART OUR IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING WHILE ALSO MAINTAINING OUR NEW VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING, WHICH HAS ALLOWED US TO REACH A WIDER AND MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCE THAN EVER BEFORE. HOWEVER, OUR VIRTUAL EVENTS HAVE NOT BROUGHT IN THE INCOME REQUIRED TO FULLY FUND OUR FULL-TIME PUBLIC PROGRAMS DIRECTOR POSITION. WE ARE REQUESTING FOUR MONTHS OF SALARY AND BENEFITS FOR OUR FULL-TIME PUBLIC PROGRAMS DIRECTOR, SO THAT WE CAN FULLY FUND THE POSITION WHILE WE RESTART PLANNING, MARKETING, AND IMPLEMENTING A SCHEDULE OF IN-PERSON EVENTS. ONCE IN-PERSON EVENTS RESUME WE EXPECT TO SEE AN INCREASE IN EARNED INCOME AS WELL AS AN INCREASE IN ASSOCIATED DONATIONS AND ANNUAL MEMBERSHIP FEES THAT WILL ALLOW US TO FULLY FUND THIS POSITION AFTER THE NEH FUNDS ARE EXPENDED.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT TO THE WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION IS TO FACILITATE THE PLANNING, MARKETING, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW IN-PERSON PROGRAMS AT A HISTORIC HOUSE IN ASHEVILLE, NORTH CAROLINA, RETAINING ONE STAFF POSITION.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA HISTORICAL ASSOCIATION WILL RETURN TO IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING AND MAINTAIN ITS VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING. AN AWARD IN LITERARY EXCELLENCE ABOUT WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA WILL BE INITIATED. LECTURES ABOUT PEOPLE, HISTORY, AND CULTURES OF WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA DELIVERED BY SCHOLARS AND REGIONAL HISTORIANS, FOCUSING ON NATIVE AMERICAN (PRIMARILY CHEROKEE) CULTURE AND AFRICAN-AMERICAN HERITAGE. EDUCATIONAL PACKAGES ABOUT WOODLAND INDIANS, THE CIVIL WAR, AND MYSTERIES IN HISTORY FOR THE GRADES K-12 AND UTILIZING REAL HISTORICAL ARTIFACTS?WILL BE PREPARED. MEETINGS WITH STUDENTS TO ENGAGE IN A HISTORICAL ACTIVITY AND WORKING ON A THEMED PROJECT FOR ANNUAL STATE COMPETITIONS WILL BE ORGANIZED. THE ASSOCIATION WILL RESUME BI-MONTHLY HIKES AND WALKING TOURS FOR ADULTS TO HISTORIC LOCATIONS GUIDED BY PROFESSIONAL HISTORIANS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE ASSOCIATION WILL RESUME ITS IN PERSON ACTIVITIES WITHOUT COMPROMISING ITS ONLINE SUCCESS, REENGAGE WITH THE YOUNGER AND OLDER AUDIENCES IN A SEE MANNER, RESUME ITS FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES WITHOUT DELAY AND REALIZE ITS PERVIOUS ECONOMIC STATUS WITHOUT DELAY, WHILE SERVING ITS POPULAR AND SCHOLARLY PURPOSE OF PUBLIC HUMANITIES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC, STUDENTS, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, AND THE MUSEUM STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

HISTORIC ROYCROFT CAMPUS - WELCOMING GUESTS BACK TO A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK [WITH THIS FUNDING, THE HISTORIC ROYCROFT CAMPUS WILL BE ABLE TO EXPAND/RESUME ITS ABILITY TO WELCOME GUESTS TO THE MUSEUM, PRESS ROOM, AND VISITOR CENTER AND CONTINUE IMPORTANT WORK RELATED TO ITS HISTORIC COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: - EXPAND HOURS OF OPERATION IN THE MUSEUM, PRESS ROOM, AND VISITOR CENTER DUE TO HAVING A FULL-TIME EMPLOYEE DEDICATED TO THIS WORK. - MAKE MODIFICATIONS TO THE PRESS ROOM AND MUSEUM TO ALLOW FOR SOCIAL DISTANCING AND IMPROVED SAFETY AND SANITATION. - CONTINUE COLLECTIONS MAINTENANCE AND EXHIBIT CURATION TO ENSURE THE SAFETY, PROPER ORGANIZATION, RELEVANCE, AND INTEREST OF THE CAMPUS? HISTORIC COLLECTION. - DIGITIZE PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIAL FROM THE COLLECTION FOR REMOTE PUBLIC RESEARCH.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE ROYCROFT MUSEUM WILL BE USED TO RESUME THE MUSEUM ACTIVITIES. THE MUSEUM WILL WELCOME GUESTS TO ITS PRESS ROOM AND VISITOR CENTER AND CONTINUE ITS WORK RELATED TO ITS HISTORIC COLLECTION. THE GRANT WILL SUPPORT ONE JOB AND A PAY FOR A PORTION OF A SECOND POSITION.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;WITH AN AWAD, THE ROYCROFT MUSEUM WILL BE ABLE TO EXTEND OPERATING HOURS AT ITS PRESS ROOM WAND VISITOR CENTER. NEW LIGHTING AND NEW DISPLAY CASES WILL BE INSTALLED, AND&NBSP;NEW SAFETY INITIATIVES WILL ACCOMMODATE THE TOURS AND DEMONSTRATIONS.PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIAL FROM THE COLLECTION WILL BE DIGITIZED FOR REMOTE USE BY HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, SCHOOLTEACHERS, AND ANYONE WHO WOULD PREFER TO ACCESS COLLECTIONS IN LIEU OF THEIR VISITING IN PERSON. MUSEUM'S ON-LINE PRESENCE WILL BE UPDATED TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF ITS GROWING TRAFFIC IN THE POST-PANDEMIC ENVIRONMENT.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE MOST IMPORTANT EXPECTED OUTCOME IS A SAFER AND MORE SANITARY ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH THE MUSEUM CAN CONTINUE ITS ACTIVITIES. OTHER OUTCOMES INCLUDE A BETTER ONLINE PRESENCE FOR THE MUSEUM AND DIGITIZED ARCHIVAL ACCESS FOR THE HUMANITIES SCHOLARS.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, AND THE MUSEUM STAFF IN PARTICULAR.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

CONNECTING COMMUNITIES THROUGH LITERATURE [THIS PROJECT WILL 1) PROVIDE EIGHT, 8-WEEK LITERATURE READING AND DISCUSSION PROGRAMS FOR 120-160 MARGINALIZED PARTICIPANTS WITH LIMITED OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN CIVIC DISCOURSE AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING, AND 2) SUPPORT THE HIRING OF A PUBLIC HUMANITIES SCHOLAR WHO WILL ADVANCE STRATEGIC GOALS SET FORTH BY PEOPLE & STORIES/GENTE Y CUENTOS' STRATEGIC PLANNING COMMITTEE.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO GENTE Y CUENTOS WILL SUPPORT AN 8-WEEK LITERATURE READING AND DISCUSSION PROGRAM FOR 120-160 MARGINALIZED PARTICIPANTS WITH LIMITED OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN CIVIC DISCOURSE AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING. THE AWARD WILL HELP HIRE A PROGRAM MANAGER AND SIX FACILITATORS FOR THE PROJECT.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;GENTE Y CUENTOS WILL IMPLEMENT AN 8-WEEK READING AND DISCUSSION PROGRAM IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH AND HIRE A PROGRAM MANAGER AND SIX PROGRAM FACILITATORS. IN TOTAL, 64 READING AND DISCUSSION SESSIONS WILL FOCUS ON TWO IMPORTANT HUMANITIES THEMES: IDENTITIES AND COMMUNITIES. IDENTITY WILL BE DISCUSSED THROUGH EXAMINING MULTICULTURAL STORIES AND EXPLORATION OF THE TENSIONS BETWEEN PEOPLE AND THEIR SURROUNDING ENVIRONMENTS. THE WAYS IN WHICH THE STORIES REPRESENT DIFFERENT IDENTITIES AND HOW THEY MIRROR OR CONFLICT WITH PARTICIPANTS' OWN EXPERIENCES WILL BE REFLECTED ON. PARTICIPANTS WILL BE INVITED TO EXPLORE THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF COMMUNITY MEMBERSHIP.?&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE PARTICIPANTS? UNDERSTANDING OF COMMUNITY ACROSS DIFFERENT CULTURES. THEY WILL BECOME ACTIVE EXAMINERS OF WHAT IT MEANS TO DEVELOP AN IDENTITY AND BE AFFILIATED WITH A COMMUNITY. THEY WILL BE USE LITERATURE AS A MEANS OF CRITICAL THINKING. THEY WILL BE ENCOURAGED IN TERMS OF SELF-ASSURANCE, AND MOTIVATED TO PARTICIPATE IN PUBLIC HUMANITIES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;120-160 PARTICIPANTS WHO OTHERWISE HAVE LIMITED ACCESS TO PUBLIC HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING AND THE PROGRAM STAFF IN PARTICULAR, AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES IN GENERAL.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

REQUEST FOR SUPPORT OF OUR CORE HISTORY-FOCUSED PROGRAMMING [THIS PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON THE EXPANSION OF THE CENTER FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN MILITARY HISTORY DBA THE BUFFALO SOLDIER NATIONAL MUSEUM'S CORE HISTORY RELATED PROGRAMMING. SPECIFICALLY, WE HAVE IDENTIFIED A NEED FOR SUPPORT OF OUR ORAL HISTORY COLLECTION EFFORTS, OUR LIVING HISTORY RE-ENACTMENT PROGRAM AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INTERACTIVE MAP OF THE HISTORICAL BUFFALO SOLDIER TRAIL TO SUPPORT OUR HISTORY IN THE NOW PROGRAMMING. OUR HISTORY IN THE NOW PROGRAMS ENGAGE A WIDE AND DIVERSE AUDIENCE IN EXPLORING THE HISTORY AND IMPACT AFRICAN AMERICAN SERVICEMEN AND WOMEN IN THE UNITED STATES AND WILL ENCOURAGE AN INFORMED AND OPEN PUBLIC DISCUSSION TO DEEPEN AN UNDERSTANDING OF PLACES, OBJECTS, AND INTANGIBLE HERITAGE THAT OFFER A DIVERSE EXPLORATION OF THE PAST.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE CENTER FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN MILITARY HISTORY WILL SUPPORT THE CREATION OF PROGRAMMING EXPLORING THE HISTORY AND IMPACT OF AFRICAN AMERICAN SERVICEMEN AND WOMEN IN THE UNITED STATES MILITARY. THE GRANT WILL ENABLE THE CENTER TO RETAIN FIVE JOBS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE CENTER WILL HOLD TRAINING SESSIONS FOR ITS STAFF IN ORAL HISTORY METHODOLOGY, THEORY AND DESIGN. IT WILL TRAIN THE STAFF ON EQUIPMENT USE AND ETHICAL STANDARDS OF COLLECTING ORAL HISTORIES AND ENSURE THAT THE ORAL HISTORIES ARE COLLECTED, TRANSCRIBED, AND PREPARED AT AN ARCHIVAL STANDARD. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE THE NECESSARY EQUIPMENT FOR THE RECORDING AND STORAGE OF THE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTION. THE EMERGING COLLECTION OF ORAL HISTORY WILL BE USED TO ENHANCE THE EXISTING EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DEVELOP A PROGRAM TITLED LIVING HISTORY. THE GRANT WILL COVER THE COST OF HIRING HISTORICAL ACTORS TO TELL THE STORIES OF AFRICAN AMERICANS DURING, BEFORE, AND AFTER THE CIVIL WAR. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE AN INTERACTIVE DISPLAY FOR ITS ALREADY DIGITIZED COLLECTION ABOUT THE BUFFALO SOLDIERS TRAIL.'THE MUSEUM'S DIVERSE AUDIENCE WILL EXPLORE THE HISTORY AND IMPACT OF AFRICAN AMERICAN SERVICEMEN AND WOMEN.'THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE A MORE MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIP WITH ITS OLD PARTNERS LIKE COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, LOCAL PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS, COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES, RESEARCH CENTERS, LOCAL AND STATE ART ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESS GROUPS, AND VETERAN ASSOCIATIONS. THE 30,000 ANNUAL VISITS THESE RELATIONSHIPS HAVE PRODUCED WILL BE ENHANCED.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;MOST IMPORTANT EXPECTED OUTCOME IS THAT THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS IMPORTANCE IN PUBLIC HUMANITIES AND ITS COMMUNITY. THIS WILL SPUR THE GROWTH OF PARTNERSHIPS WITH PEER ORGANIZATIONS AND HELP DEVELOP AND LAUNCH TRAVELING EXHIBITIONS. THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO EXPAND HUMANITIES-BASED PROGRAMMING WILL HELP THE PUBLIC TO ENGAGE WITH HISTORY IN A MORE SIGNIFICANT WAY.'&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES EXPERTS AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES SPECIALISTS, COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND THE MUSEUM STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

INVISIBLE WOMEN: TELLING THE UNTOLD STORIES AT NEW YORK'S PHILIPSBURG AND VAN CORTLANDT MANORS [HHV REQUESTS A GRANT TO HIRE AND TRAIN STAFF AND INTERPRETERS WHO WILL CREATE AND SUSTAIN A LIVE, DIGITAL SCHOOL PROGRAM ABOUT THE EXPERIENCES OF ENSLAVED AND FREE WOMEN IN COLONIAL AND POST-REVOLUTIONARY AMERICA. THESE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS, DESIGNED WITH MEANINGFUL INPUT FROM EDUCATOR AND STUDENT EVALUATORS, BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF OUR AWARD-WINNING NEH-FUNDED DOCUMENTARY PEOPLE NOT PROPERTY: STORIES OF SLAVERY IN THE COLONIAL NORTH. INVISIBLE WOMEN SEEKS TO FLIP THE TRADITIONAL NARRATIVE, ONE BASED ON DOCUMENTS THAT MARGINALIZE THE PRESENCE OF MOTHERS, WIVES, AND DAUGHTERS, NOT TO MENTION SKILLED FEMALE LABORERS AND ENTREPRENEURS. IT WOULD PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO AMPLIFY VOICES THAT ARE RARELY HEARD AND SHOWCASE CONTRASTING EXPERIENCES THAT OFFER A PROFOUND AND COMPLICATED PORTRAIT OF A NATION IN PROGRESS. THE GRANT WOULD ALLOW HHV TO ADDRESS THE PANDEMIC-DRIVEN DEMAND FOR ONLINE ENGAGEMENT IN THE HUMANITIES AND SUSTAIN HHV AS A CRITICAL EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY WILL BE USED TO HIRE AND TRAIN STAFF AND INTERPRETERS WHO WILL CREATE AND SUSTAIN A LIVE, DIGITAL SCHOOL PROGRAM ABOUT THE EXPERIENCES OF ENSLAVED AND FREE WOMEN IN COLONIAL AND POST-REVOLUTIONARY AMERICA. THE GRANT WILL ALLOW HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY TO ADDRESS THE PANDEMIC-DRIVEN DEMAND FOR ONLINE ENGAGEMENT IN PUBLIC HUMANITIES AND SUSTAIN THEM AS A CRITICAL EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY WILL CREATE AND SUSTAIN AN INTERACTIVE DIGITAL SCHOOL PROGRAM FOCUSING ON THE LIVED EXPERIENCES OF ENSLAVED AND FREE WOMEN IN COLONIAL AND POST-REVOLUTIONARY AMERICA. INTERPRETIVE STAFF WILL BE HIRED AND TRAINED TO PARTICIPATE IN DIGITAL CONTENT DELIVERY AND AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT AND TAUGHT TO USE VIDEO TECHNOLOGY. FIELD TRIPS WILL BE HELD TO FOCUS ON THE UNIQUE INTERIOR SPACES THAT WERE THE DOMAIN OF WOMEN AND TO ENCOURAGE STUDENT ENGAGEMENT. INTERPRETIVE STAFF, LED BY THE DIGITAL CONTENT CREATOR WILL BE TRAINED TO DELIVER HISTORICAL INTERPRETATION. LIVE FIELD TRIPS WILL BE ORGANIZED AND SUPPLIED WITH CRITICAL THINKING PROMPTS SUCH AS PHOTOGRAPHS, OBJECTS AND MAPS TO ENCOURAGE GEOGRAPHIC KNOWLEDGE. EXISTING DIGITAL TOOLS WILL BE CUSTOMIZED FOR TEACHING HISTORY OF NORTHERN SLAVERY AND A HIGH-QUALITY DIGITAL IMAGES COLLECTION WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR FUTURE DISTANCE LEARNING INITIATIVES. INDIVIDUAL EDUCATOR AND STUDENT FOCUS GROUPS WILL BE CONVENED TO ASSESS SCRIPTS, ENGAGEMENT STRATEGIES, DELIVERY METHODS, AND DIGITAL MATERIAL CREATED THROUGH THIS GRANT.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;INVISIBLE WOMEN EXHIBITION WILL CHANGE THE TRADITIONAL NARRATIVE BY SHIFTING THE FOCUS FROM DOCUMENTS THAT MARGINALIZE THE PRESENCE OF MOTHERS, WIVES, AND DAUGHTERS, WHICH DO NOT MENTION SKILLED FEMALE LABORERS AND ENTREPRENEURS. IT WILL AMPLIFY THEIR VOICES, SHOWCASE THEIR CONTRASTING EXPERIENCES AND INFORM VISITORS ABOUT THE COMPLICATED PORTRAIT OF THE NATION IN PROGRESS. THE GRANT WILL ALSO ALLOW HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY TO ANSWER THE DEMAND FOR ONLINE ENGAGEMENT IN PUBLIC HUMANITIES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GGENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, US HISTORIANS, AND MEMBERS OF THE MUSEUM STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;A PORTION OF THE AWARD TO HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY WILL GO TO TURNSTILE STUDIO, A FIRM THAT SUPPORTS CAPACITY-BUILDING BY CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS THROUGH PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES. TURNSTILE WILL HOLD WORKSHOPS FOCUSING ON TRANSLATING INTERPRETIVE TECHNIQUES FOR VIRTUAL PRESENTATION, DEVELOPING STRATEGIES FOR INQUIRY-BASED LEARNING AND DIALOGUE FACILITATION AROUND CHALLENGING TOPICS. THE SUBAWARD WILL ALSO CREATE ORIGINAL TRAINING MATERIALS TO SUSTAIN THE PROJECT BEYOND THE LIFE OF THE GRANT.]

RE-ESTABLISHING AFRICAN AMERICAN AND DIASPORIC HUMANITIES PUBLIC PROGRAMS AT THE ATLANTA UNIVERSITY CENTER WOODRUFF LIBRARY [THE ATLANTA UNIVERSITY CENTER (AUC) WOODRUFF LIBRARY SEEKS $220,400 IN FUNDING FOR A PROJECT TO REESTABLISH AFRICAN AMERICAN AND DIASPORIC HUMANITIES PUBLIC PROGRAMS, RECOGNIZING THE LIVES AND WORKS OF UNDERREPRESENTED SCHOLARS AND ACTIVISTS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC IMPACTED THE LIBRARY?S ABILITY TO HOST THREE EXISTING SYMPOSIA AND SPEAKERS SERIES PROGRAMS ? TRADITIONALLY HELD IN PERSON ? IN 2020 AND 2021. THESE FREE HUMANITIES PUBLIC EVENTS DREW LARGE PARTICIPATION, FOSTERED COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, BROADENED AWARENESS OF HISTORICAL RESOURCES, AND SPARKED HUMANITIES DISCOURSE IN THE AUC ? THE LARGEST CONSORTIUM OF HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES IN THE WORLD. WITH SUPPORT, STAFF WILL PLAN AND EXECUTE THE RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF PROGRAMS ON ASA G. HILLIARD, III AND WALTER RODNEY, AS WELL AS CREATE A NEW PROGRAM HONORING JOSEPH E. AND EVELYN G. LOWERY. DIGITAL EXHIBITIONS WILL BE CURATED TO PROVIDE VIRTUAL ACCESS, AND ENHANCE THE UNIQUE, ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS OF THESE INDIVIDUALS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN FIVE POSITIONS AND REESTABLISH HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING RELATED TO AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY, LIFE, AND CULTURE AT A LIBRARY IN ATLANTA, GEORGIA.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FIVE STAFF POSITIONS WILL BE RETAINED AT THE ROBERT W. WOODRUFF LIBRARY OF THE ATLANTA UNIVERSITY CENTER AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING WILL BE RESUMED. STAFF WILL REESTABLISH TWO EXISTING SYMPOSIUMS RELATED TO THE LIBRARY?S COLLECTIONS THAT WERE PUT ON HOLD DUE TO THE PANDEMIC, AND CREATE A NEW ARCHIVAL PROGRAM RELATED TO AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY. STAFF WILL ENGAGE IN RESEARCH, PLANNING, PROMOTION, AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAMMING, WHICH INCLUDES HOSTING SPEAKERS? SERIES, CREATING EXHIBITIONS, AND FACILITATING SCHOLARLY RESEARCH ON THE LIBRARY?S HOLDINGS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;FUNDING WILL SUSTAIN EXISTING PUBLIC AND SCHOLARLY HUMANITIES PROGRAMS AND RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STUDENTS AND FACULTY AT THE ATLANTA UNIVERSITY CENTER, THE LARGEST CONSORTIUM OF HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES IN THE COUNTRY, AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

FROM ABSENCE TO PRESENCE AND BEYOND: EXTENDING THE HISTORY AND VOICES OF ENSLAVED PEOPLES OF SOUTHERN MARYLAND [EXTENSION OF RESEARCH AND PROGRAMMING FOR THE RECENTLY DISCOVERED HISTORY OF ENSLAVED PEOPLES OF SOUTHERN MARYLAND THROUGH THE CREATION OF ONE 1-YEAR FULL-TIME POSITION FOR A PUBLIC HUMANITIES FELLOW. THIS FELLOW WILL CARRY OUT LONG-TERM STRATEGIC AND IMPLEMENTATION PLANNING AND AID IN SUSTAINING AND EXPANDING EXISTING HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING WITH ST. MARY?S COLLEGE OF MARYLAND?S NEWLY DEDICATED COMMEMORATIVE TO ENSLAVED PEOPLES OF SOUTHERN MARYLAND AND THE AFRICAN AND AFRICAN DIASPORA STUDIES AND MUSEUM STUDIES PROGRAMS.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO HIRE A SCHOLAR TRAINED IN THE PUBLIC HUMANITIES TO DO RESEARCH AND CREATE HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING AT A PUBLIC COLLEGE IN MARYLAND.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A SCHOLAR WILL BE HIRED TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND CREATE PROGRAMMING ON THE HISTORY OF ENSLAVED PEOPLES IN SOUTHERN MARYLAND. THE SCHOLAR WILL DESIGN AND EXECUTE ACADEMIC AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING WITH FACULTY AND STAFF COLLABORATORS FROM THE AFRICAN AND AFRICAN DIASPORA STUDIES AND MUSEUM STUDIES PROGRAMS. HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE ACADEMIC LECTURES, MUSEUM AND HERITAGE WORKSHOPS, AND PUBLIC DISCUSSIONS ON THE HISTORY OF SLAVERY.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE CREATION OF A SCHOLARLY PUBLIC HUMANITIES POSITION TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND EXECUTE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND STAFF AT THE COLLEGE, AS WELL AS THE LOCAL COMMUNITY.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

CLARK ART INSTITUTE: PUBLIC, ACADEMIC, LIBRARY, AND SCHOOL HUMANITIES PROGRAMS [THE STERLING AND FRANCINE CLARK ART INSTITUTE REQUESTS $500,000 TO HELP SUPPORT ITS PUBLIC, ACADEMIC, SCHOOL, AND LIBRARY HUMANITIES PROGRAMS. SINCE THE PANDEMIC CRISIS BEGAN, THE CLARK HAS FOCUSED ON RETAINING PERMANENT STAFF WHILE PROVIDING PROGRAMS VIRTUALLY TO ITS CORE AUDIENCES AND KEEPING ITS CAMPUS OPEN FOR RECREATION AND RESPITE. WITH SUPPORT FROM NEH, THE CLARK SEEKS NOW TO RESTORE IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING WHILE CONTINUING TO OFFER EXPANDED VIRTUAL PROGRAMS; TO INCLUDE GUEST SCHOLARS, ARTISTS, AND OTHER VOICES IN PROGRAMS; TO ENHANCE ONLINE CONTENT FEATURING CLARK COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITIONS; AND TO SECURE THE STAFF POSITIONS AND OTHER RESOURCES NECESSARY TO IMPLEMENT THIS AMBITIOUS SLATE OF PROGRAMS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT SEVEN STAFF POSITIONS THAT WILL HELP SUSTAIN CORE PUBLIC, ACADEMIC, SCHOOL, AND LIBRARY HUMANITIES PROGRAMS AT THE STERLING AND FRANCINE CLARK ART INSTITUTE IN MASSACHUSETTS.&NBSP;&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A TOTAL OF SEVEN STAFF POSITIONS WILL BE RETAINED OR HIRED IN SUPPORT OF THE STERLING AND FRANCINE CLARK ART INSTITUTE'S CORE HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING, WHICH INCLUDES LIBRARY COLLECTIONS, CULTURAL EXHIBITIONS, AND ACADEMIC PROGRAMS. STAFF WILL BE REINSTATED THAT ARE CRITICAL TO RUNNING THE INSTITUTE'S "CLARK CONNECTS" DIGITAL PROGRAMMING AND ADVANCE DIGITAL COMPONENTS OF HUMANITIES PROGRAMS. IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING, INCLUDING ACADEMIC LECTURES AND WORKSHOPS, WILL BE RESUMED.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;FUNDING WILL MAINTAIN AND EXPAND EXISTING PUBLIC, ACADEMIC, SCHOOL, AND LIBRARY PROGRAMS AND RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE AUDIENCE FOR THE INSTITUTE'S HUMANITIES PROGRAMING AND LIBRARY INCLUDES ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, K-12 AND COLLEGE STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

#ENFIELDEVERYWHERE: PLANNING AND DEVELOPING INTEGRATED PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL EXHIBITION SITES TO COMMEMORATE THE 250TH ANNIVERSARY OF SHAKERISM IN AMERICA AT ENFIELD SHAKER MUSEUM [ENFIELD SHAKER MUSEUM WILL PLAN, DEVELOP, AND SCRIPT TWO DISTINCT BUT COMPLEMENTARY EXHIBITIONS TO OPEN IN 2024, THE 250TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE ARRIVAL OF THE SHAKERS? FOUNDER, ANN LEE, TO AMERICA. THESE EXHIBITIONS?ONE A PHYSICAL SITE AND THE OTHER DIGITAL?WILL BE INTEGRATED WITH THE MUSEUM?S WEBSITE AND SOCIAL MEDIA DURING AND AFTER THE PROJECT?S COMPLETION (2023-2026). THE PHYSICAL SITE EXHIBITION WILL EXPLORE SHAKER RELIGIOUS TENETS AND THEIR SOCIAL MANIFESTATIONS AS COMMUNALISM, GENDER AND RACIAL EQUALITY, AND PACIFISM, AS WELL AS THEIR REIFICATION IN THE SHAKERS' MATERIAL CULTURE AND BUILT ENVIRONMENT AND SHAPING OF THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT. THE EXHIBITION WEBSITE (#ENFIELDEVERYWHERE) WILL INCLUDE ENFIELD ARTIFACTS AND DOCUMENTS AT ENFIELD AND AT OTHER MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES AND IN PRIVATE HANDS, A DATABASE OF ENFIELD SHAKERS (ALREADY IN PRODUCTION), AND AN EXPANSION OF THEMES BEYOND THE PHYSICAL EXHIBITION'S CAPACITY.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN AND HIRE NEW MUSEUM STAFF, AND FUND WORK RELATED TO HISTORICAL EXHIBITIONS AT A MUSEUM IN NEW HAMPSHIRE.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TWO FULL-TIME POSITIONS, A MUSEUM CURATOR AND AN EDUCATION COORDINATOR, WILL BE RETAINED UNDER THE GRANT AND TWO NEW PART-TIME POSITIONS WILL BE HIRED. MUSEUM STAFF WILL CREATE TWO EXHIBITIONS ON THE HISTORY OF THE SHAKER RELIGION AND ITS HISTORICAL ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNALISM, PACIFISM, AND GENDER AND RACIAL EQUALITY. STAFF WILL PLAN AND DEVELOP ONE EXHIBITION ON-SITE AT THE MUSEUM AND EXPAND DIGITAL CONTENT FOR AN ONLINE EXHIBITION.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;FUNDING WILL MAINTAIN AND EXPAND EXISTING HUMANITIES PROGRAMS AND RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: LONG-TIME LOCAL AND REGIONAL MUSEUM MEMBERS, DONORS, STUDENTS, VOLUNTEERS, VISITORS, AND AN ONLINE AUDIENCE.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;AN EXHIBITION COORDINATOR AND HISTORY COMMUNICATOR WILL BE HIRED ON CONTRACT TO HELP DEVELOP EXHIBITION CONTENT.]

BEYOND RESILIENCE: MASTERCLASSES - EXPANDING HUMANITIES THEMES AND CULTURAL REPRESENTATION IN HISTORICAL DOCUMENTARY FILM [TO SUPPORT THE NEXT GENERATION AND DEEPEN THE ACADEMIC RIGOR OF HISTORIC NONFICTION CINEMA, FIRELIGHT MEDIA, THE PREMIERE DESTINATION FOR CINEMA BY AND ABOUT COMMUNITIES OF COLOR, WILL ENGAGE BIPOC FILMMAKERS WITH EXPERIENCES LED AND ADVISED BY ARCHIVISTS, HISTORIANS, RECOGNIZED HISTORICAL DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKERS, AND OTHER HUMANITIES SCHOLARS. WE WOULD DEVELOP AND OFFER A SERIES OF VIRTUAL MASTER CLASSES, OFFERED TO FILMMAKERS AND OTHERS NATIONALLY, THAT ADDRESS KEY TOPICS INCLUDING THE INTEGRATION OF HUMANITIES THEMES INTO DOCUMENTARY FILMS, INTERVIEW TECHNIQUES WITH HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, THE STRATEGIC USE OF ARCHIVAL IMAGES AND TEXT, AND METHODS OF POPULARIZING CRUCIAL HISTORICAL NARRATIVES IN FILM] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN FIVE POSITIONS AND DEVELOP PROGRAMMING FOR FILMMAKERS ON HOW TO INTEGRATE HUMANITIES THEMES INTO DOCUMENTARY FILMS AT A NON-PROFIT FILMMAKING ORGANIZATION IN NEW YORK.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: FIVE STAFF POSITIONS WILL BE RETAINED IN SUPPORT OF FIRELIGHT MEDIA'S MISSION TO FOSTER A DIVERSE FIELD OF PROFESSIONAL DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKERS. STAFF WILL DEVELOP A SERIES OF VIRTUAL WORKSHOPS FOR DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKERS OF COLOR THAT FOCUS ON PRODUCING&NBSP;DEEPLY RESEARCHED AND HISTORICALLY ACCURATE DOCUMENTARY FILMS. EACH WORKSHOP WILL INCLUDE EXPERT-ADVISORS, SUCH AS SCHOLARS, HISTORIANS, AND ARCHIVISTS, THAT WILL PROVIDE A SURVEY OF THE BEST METHODS OF INTEGRATING RIGOROUS SCHOLARSHIP INTO HISTORICAL DOCUMENTARIES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;FUNDING WILL CREATE A NEW SERIES OF HUMANITIES WORKSHOPS FOR DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKERS AND RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: A BROAD, DIVERSE COMMUNITY OF DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKERS AT VARYING STAGES OF THEIR CAREERS, PARTICULARLY FILMMAKERS OF COLOR, AND WITH VARYING DEGREES OF EXPERIENCE WITH OR INTEREST IN ENGAGING HISTORICAL HUMANITIES THEMES THOUGH CINEMATIC CONTENT.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

SNAPSHOT OF DEMOCRACY:  THE EIGHT OHIO PRESIDENTS [THE ALLEN COUNTY MUSEUM WILL PRESENT THE PROJECT SNAPSHOT OF DEMOCRACY: THE EIGHT OHIO PRESIDENTS. IT WILL INCLUDE THE EXHIBITION SURPRISING LEGACIES: THE OHIO PRESIDENTS; A SCHOLARLY EXHIBITION CATALOG; HUMANITIES LECTURES ON TOPICS THAT HIGHLIGHT THE POLITICAL HISTORY AND DEMOCRACY OF OUR COUNTRY AND OHIO; AND A MUSICAL ENSEMBLE PERFORMANCE BY THE LIMA SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA OF MUSIC FROM THE PERIOD 1840-1920 AS IT ALIGNS WITH THE TIME OHIO HAD EIGHT PRESIDENTS IN OFFICE. IN ADDITION, VARIOUS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL BE PRESENTED FROM SCHOOL TOURS TO CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT TO A BOOK CLUB HOSTED BY THE ALLEN COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY. TO FURTHER CONSIDER SAFETY REQUIREMENTS DUE TO THE PANDEMIC, TECHNOLOGICAL COMPONENTS WILL BE INCORPORATED TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO THE EXHIBIT AND LECTURES IN-PERSON AND ONLINE.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN FIVE STAFF POSITIONS, HIRE TWO NEW CURATORIAL POSITIONS, AND HOST AN EXHIBITION AT A COUNTY MUSEUM IN NORTHWEST OHIO.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: STAFF WILL PREPARE AND PRESENT AN EXHIBITION ENTITLED, ?SURPRISING LEGACIES: THE OHIO PRESIDENTS? THAT INCLUDES IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL COMPONENTS, AN EXHIBITION CATALOG, AND PUBLIC AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. PUBLIC PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE A PERFORMANCE BY THE LOCAL SYMPHONY, A LECTURE SERIES, AND A BOOK CLUB HOSTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LOCAL LIBRARY.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING WILL RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC AND ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO HOST AN EXHIBITION AND ASSOCIATED PROGRAMMING.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: REGIONAL VISITORS AND TOURISTS WHO VISIT THE MUSEUM IN PERSON, AND A BROADER PUBLIC AUDIENCE WHO CAN ACCESS VIRTUAL PROGRAMS.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

JAMESTOWN: UNEARTHING, UNDERSTANDING, AND SHARING THE ROOTS OF AMERICAN HISTORY [THE JAMESTOWN REDISCOVERY FOUNDATION (JRF) IS DEDICATED TO THE ARCHAEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATION, PRESERVATION, AND EDUCATION OF JAMESTOWN, THE FIRST SUCCESSFUL ENGLISH COLONY IN NORTH AMERICA. FUNDS WILL ENABLE JRF TO ENHANCE CURRENT AND DEVELOP NEW ON-SITE AND DIGITAL PROGRAMS IN FOUR KEY AREAS: 1) SUPPORT FOR PUBLIC ARCHAEOLOGY, ALLOWING VISITORS TO WITNESS ONGOING EXCAVATIONS AND FOLLOW OUR REMARKABLE DISCOVERIES ONLINE; 2) CREATION OF A SELF-GUIDED TOUR OF THE NATHALIE P. & ALAN M. VOORHEES ARCHAEARIUM FOR VISITORS TO ACCESS RICH CONTENT AS THEY EXPLORE THE MUSEUM; 3) DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW PLAN FOR THE ?ED SHED,? JRF?S CENTRAL VENUE FOR CHILDREN?S PROGRAMS ON-SITE, INCORPORATING COVID-19 SAFETY MEASURES; 4) EXPANSION OF ?DIGITAL REDISCOVERY,? AN ONLINE PLATFORM FEATURING VIDEOS HIGHLIGHTING ASPECTS OF JAMESTOWN?S HISTORY, THROUGH THE ADDITION OF TWO NEW TOURS, ONE ON THE COMPLEX RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN POWHATAN AND ENGLISH AND THE OTHER ON THE ARRIVAL OF THE FIRST AFRICANS IN 1619.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT NINE STAFF POSITIONS AND FOUR PROGRAMS RELATED TO THE INTERPRETATION OF THE JAMESTOWN ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE IN VIRGINIA.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: STAFF WILL DEVELOP ON-SITE AND DIGITAL PROGRAMS RELATED TO PUBLIC ARCHAEOLOGY INCLUDING A SELF-GUIDED TOUR OF AN ARCHAEOLOGY MUSEUM, CHILDREN?S PROGRAMMING, AND THE EXPANSION OF AN ONLINE PLATFORM FEATURING VIDEOS ON JAMESTOWN?S HISTORY.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING WILL SUSTAIN AND EXPAND PUBLIC ARCHAEOLOGY PROGRAMMING AND RETAIN HUMANITIES JOBS THAT WERE THREATENED BY THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO CAN VISIT THE ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE IN-PERSON AND ONLINE, AS WELL AS K-12 STUDENTS.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

HISTORY COLORADO HUMANITIES IMPACT PLAN FOR RURAL COLORADO [TO SUPPORT HISTORY COLORADO'S RETENTION OF HUMANITIES JOBS, CONTINUATION OF ADULT AND YOUTH HUMANITIES PROGRAMS, INSTALLATION OF NEW EXHIBITS, AND TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT THE DELIVERY OF SYNCHRONOUS HYBRID HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING IN RURAL COLORADO.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONTINUE ADULT AND YOUTH HUMANITIES PROGRAMS, INSTALL NEW EXHIBITS, AND IMPROVE TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE AT HISTORY COLORADO   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: HISTORY COLORADO WILL INSTALL A NEW WIRELESS NETWORK TO SUPPORT ITS EIGHT MUSEUMS. ADDITIONALLY, HISTORICAL COLORADO WILL REINTERPRET FORT GARLAND MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER AND CURATE SEVERAL NEW EXHIBITS INCLUDING THE UTE INDIAN MUSEUM TRAVELING EXHIBIT AND UNTIL IT'S OVER: THE COURAGE AND COMMITMENT OF PUEBLO AND ITS STEELWORKERS. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE REINSTITUTING PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE CENTER FOR COLORADO WOMEN'S HISTORY FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM, THE BORDERLANDS OF SOUTHERN COLORADO INITIATIVE, AND HANDS-ON-HISTORY.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: HISTORY COLORADO'S EXHIBITS AND HUMANITIES PROGRAMS WILL IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE AND ENGAGEMENT WITH COLORADO'S ETHNIC AND CULTURAL HISTORY AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO COMMUNITIES IN RURAL AREAS. THE IMPROVED WIRELESS NETWORK WILL PROVIDE RELIABLE WIRELESS SERVICE FOR VISITORS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND STAFF THROUGHOUT THE MUSEUM PROPERTIES FOR ALL COMPUTERS, PHONES, AND MOBILE DEVICES. LASTLY, THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE CURRENT BANDWIDTH AT EACH MUSEUM AND CREATE REDUNDANCY SHOULD THE PRIMARY SERVICE GO DOWN.   HISTORY COLORADO WILL RETAIN FIVE MUSEUM DIRECTORS TO MANAGE PROGRAMS AND CREATE SIX CONTRACT POSITIONS FOR HUMANITIES SCHOLARS WHO WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE FOR EXHIBIT INTERPRETATION. RA'CES DE LONG BEACH: ROOTS OF THE RANCHO [RANCHO LOS CERRITOS WILL BE PRESENTING RA'CES DE LONG BEACH: ROOTS OF THE RANCHO. STUDYING, SHARING AND PRESERVING COWBOY ARTISAN TRADITIONS [THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE HISTORY AND CURRENT CONDITIONS OF THE COWBOY ARTISAN HERITAGE IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN WEST AND NEVADA WITH THE GOAL OF BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE SOCIAL, ECONOMIC AND CULTURAL DYNAMICS NECESSARY FOR THE REVIVAL AND PRESERVATION OF THESE TRADITIONS IN THE 21ST CENTURY. THE PROJECT HAS FOUR COMPONENTS: HISTORICAL RESEARCH, RESEARCH ABOUT THE CURRENT REALITIES, A PUBLIC PROGRAM AND DIGITAL HUMANITIES. THE PUBLIC PROGRAM IS A PANEL DISCUSSION BASED ON RESEARCH, AN EXHIBITION OF MASTER WORK OF COWBOY ARTISANS AND A ONE-DAY CONFERENCE TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR COLLABORATIVE ACTION TO SUPPORT THIS HERITAGE. THE PROJECT IS A CASE STUDY FOR A HUMANITIES-DRIVEN APPROACH TO THE PRESERVATION OF ARTISAN TRADITIONS THAT COULD BE ADAPTED TO OTHER ARTISAN TRADITIONS AROUND THE WORLD. UNDERSTANDING THE PAST AND THE PRESENT IS THE KEY TO ASSURING A FUTURE. THIS PROJECT FITS WITHIN A MORE PERFECT UNION AS A CONTRIBUTION TO BUILDING A MORE INCLUSIVE AND SUSTAINABLE SOCIETY.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO HELP VISTA 360 INTERPRET ARTISAN COWBOY HERITAGE, EDUCATE FUTURE ARTISANS, AND TO PRESERVE THE COWBOY HERITAGE IN AMERICA?S WEST (ROCKY MOUNTAIN WEST AND NEVADA).  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: VISTA WILL COMPLETE A PROJECT CONSISTING OF FOUR COMPONENTS: HISTORICAL RESEARCH, CONTEMPORARY RESEARCH, PUBLIC PROGRAMMING, AND DIGITAL HUMANITIES. USING SECONDARY SOURCES AND ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL HISTORICAL SOCIETIES, VISTA WILL UNDERTAKE AN HISTORICAL INVESTIGATION OF COWBOY ARTISAN TRADITIONS IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION (MONTANA, IDAHO, WYOMING, UTAH, COLORADO) AND IN THE GREAT BASIN OF NEVADA. THE SECOND RESEARCH COMPONENT WILL FOCUS ON THE CONTEMPORARY STATE OF COWBOY ARTISAN PRODUCTION IN THIS REGION. PUBLIC PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE A PANEL DISCUSSION FEATURING MASTER ARTISANS AND STAFF MEMBERS, A ONE-DAY MICRO-CONFERENCE TO DISCUSS RESEARCH, AND A DIGITAL HUMANITIES PRESENTATION TO MAKE THE RESEARCH, PANEL DISCUSSION, AND THE CONFERENCE AVAILABLE TO ONLINE AUDIENCES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: VISTA WILL CREATE PROGRAMS TO PRESERVE ARTISAN TRADITIONS AND HISTORY AND PROVIDE MEANINGFUL LIVELIHOODS TO ARTISANS IN THE 21ST CENTURY. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT TWO EXISTING POSITIONS AND ONE NEW POSITION.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: LOCAL COMMUNITIES, VISITORS, CURRENT AND FUTURE ARTISANS, AND SCHOLARS AND GENERAL AUDIENCES INTERESTED IN US HISTORY, AMERICAN STUDIES AND CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY WILL BENEFIT FROM VISTA?S RESEARCH AND PROGRAMS DEDICATED TO THE ARTISTAN TRADITION.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES INITIATIVE [LED BY THE NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM OF UTAH (NHMU), THE NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES INITIATIVE WILL PRESERVE, AMPLIFY, AND CELEBRATE THE STORIES OF UTAH'S INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES TO HELP BUILD A MORE JUST AND INCLUSIVE SOCIETY. THE TRAGIC LOSS OF LIFE OF NATIVE AMERICAN ELDERS, IN PARTICULAR, HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE URGENT NEED TO PRESERVE TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE AND INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES. NHMU WILL COLLABORATE WITH NATIVE COMMUNITIES TO DOCUMENT INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE IN THE MUSEUM'S ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS AND DELIVER COMMUNITY-CENTERED EXHIBITIONS, EDUCATION, AND PROGRAMMING. THROUGH DEEP AND TRUSTED RELATIONSHIPS WITH UTAH TRIBES'AND IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE TANNER HUMANITIES CENTER'NHMU WILL USE ITS PLATFORM AS A PUBLIC-FACING MUSEUM TO AMPLIFY UNDER-REPRESENTED VOICES, SHOWCASE DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES, AND PRESERVE NEW KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ARTIFACTS, HISTORY, AND CULTURE.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DOCUMENT THE KNOWLEDGE OF UTAH'S INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH'S NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM OF UTAH (NHMU)AND CREATE A DIGITAL REPOSITORY TO SHARE AND STORE ETHNOGRAPHIC DATA AND ORAL HISTORIES.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE NHMU WILL REINTERPRET CURRENT ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITS AT THE NATIONAL HISTORY MUSEUM OF UTAH (NHMU) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH, TO REFLECT NATIVE AMERICAN EXPERIENCES. THE NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES INITIATIVE HAS THREE MAIN COMPONENTS: I) DOCUMENT NATIVE AMERICAN KNOWLEDGE IN THE MUSEUM'S ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS, II) COLLABORATE WITH NATIVE COMMUNITIES TO SHARE KNOWLEDGE, III) DELIVER COMMUNITY-CENTERED EXHIBITIONS, EDUCATION, AND PROGRAMMING.   IN COLLABORATION WITH NATIVE EXPERTS, NHMU WILL COLLECT ORAL HISTORIES AND DOCUMENT PREVIOUSLY UNTOLD STORIES. THE NHMU WILL THEN DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND CREATE A DIGITAL REPOSITORY THAT ALLOWS ETHNOGRAPHIC DATA AND ORAL HISTORIES TO BE SHARED WITHIN INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES.  THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES SUMMER WORKSHOPS FOR K-12 TEACHERS AND FOUR PUBLIC EDUCATION PROGRAMS: I) LAND ACKNOWLEDGEMENT II) NATIVE AMERICAN ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE PROGRAM, III) AUTHOR MEETS READERS SERIES, AND AN IV) INDIGENOUS PEOPLE'S DAY CELEBRATION. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INSTALLING VIDEO KIOSKS AND ADDING OVERLAYS TO EXHIBITS.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES INITIATIVE WILL PRESERVE, AMPLIFY, AND SHARE THE STORIES OF UTAH'S INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES AND PROMOTE A MORE INCLUSIVE NARRATIVE OF THE HISTORY AND CULTURE OF UTAH. THE DIGITAL REPOSITORY WILL ENSURE THAT THESE STORIES ARE ACCESSIBLE TO TRIBAL MEMBERS AND SCHOLARS WORLDWIDE.   THE UNIVERSITY WILL RETAIN 26 KEY STAFF MEMBERS AND HIRE 16 NATIVE CONSULTANTS AND 6 GRADUATE STUDENTS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT THE INITIATIVE.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE GENERAL PUBLIC, MUSEUM VISITORS, SCHOLARS, AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES LOCALLY AND NATIONWIDE WILL BENEFIT FROM THE NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES INITIATIVE.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUB AWARD FUNDS.]

ARTISANS AND INTERPRETATION AT VERMILIONVILLE [TO ENGAGE GUESTS WITH UNIQUE CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL EXPERIENCES THROUGH HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES. SINCE ITS CONCEPTION, ONE OF THE PRIMARY ELEMENTS OF VERMILIONVILLE'S APPROACH, AND ALSO WHAT MAKES IT DISTINCTIVE IN THE REGION, IS THAT IT OFFERS GUESTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENGAGE WITH HISTORY AND CULTURE THROUGH HANDS-ON INTERACTIONS WITH OUR ARTISANS. EACH OF OUR ARTISANS IS TRAINED IN CULTURAL CRAFT AND TRADE THAT WOULD HAVE BEEN PRACTICED BY ACADIANS, NATIVE AMERICANS, AND CREOLES AND PEOPLE OF AFRICAN DESCENT IN OUR REGION DURING THE PERIOD BETWEEN 1760 AND 1890. NOT ONLY DO OUR INTERPRETERS DEMONSTRATE THESE CRAFTS, BUT THEY CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR GUESTS TO EXPERIENCE THIS HISTORY AS WELL. WHETHER IT'S GINNING AND SPINNING COTTON, FEEDING LIVESTOCK, PLAYING A 'TIT FERE WITH A CREOLE MUSICIAN, OR PULLING A FERRY ACROSS THE BAYOU, OUR ARTISANS' OFFERINGS OF THESE UNIQUE EXPERIENCES HELP TO IMMERSE EACH GUEST IN THE HISTORY AND UNIQUE CONTEMPORARY FOLKLIFE OF OUR REGION.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL EXPERIENCES AT VERMILIONVILLE LIVING HISTORY MUSEUM, INCLUDING PROVIDING GUESTS WITH INFORMATION TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF FOLKLIFE TRADITIONS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: VERMILIONVILLE WILL RESUME PROVIDING HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES THAT REFLECT CRAFT AND TRADE PRACTICED BY ACADIANS, NATIVE AMERICANS, AND CREOLES AND PEOPLE OF AFRICAN DESCENT IN THE REGION DURING THE PERIOD BETWEEN 1760 AND 1890. ARTISANS, OR INTERPRETERS, WILL PROVIDE GUESTS WITH INFORMATION ABOUT THE HISTORICAL TRADES AND CRAFTS OF THE REGION AND GUIDE GUESTS THROUGH CRAFTING ACTIVITIES. CRAFTING ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO QUILTING, WEAVING, COOKING OVER A HEARTH, PLAYING THE TRIANGLE ALONGSIDE PROMINENT CAJUN MUSICIANS, FEEDING LIVESTOCK, LEARNING TO QUILT, LEARNING TO DANCE JUR?.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE GUESTS WITH AN INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL AND CULTURAL EXPERIENCE AND A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT AND PARTICIPATE IN RARE AMERICAN FOLKLIFE TRADITIONS. VERMILIONVILLE WILL RETAIN GIVE PART-TIME ARTISANS TO FACILITATE THE ACTIVITIES.   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: MUSEUM GUEST AND ARTISAN WORKERS WILL BENEFIT FROM VERMILIONVILLE?S UNIQUE CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL ACTIVITIES.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

THE ENGAGED LEARNING THAT AUDIENCES WILL ENJOY THROUGH THESE VIRTUAL AND ON-SITE PROGRAMS WILL ENABLE THE SHIP TO SPEAK TO TODAY?S AUDIENCES WITH ITS FULLEST VOICE, DEMONSTRATING 223-YEARS OF RESILIENCE AND COURAGE.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE USS CONSTITUTION MUSEUM WILL SUPPORT THE CREATION OF HANDS ON EXPERIENCES AND VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN. IT WILL?RETAIN SEVEN STAFF AND RESTORE FOUR PART-TIME POSITIONS WHICH WERE PUT ON HOLD DUE TO THE PANDEMIC.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;WITH THE AWARD, THE MUSEUM WILL RETURN TO ITS ON-SITE HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING AND RESUME ITS STAFF-LED INTERACTIONS. A NEW SCHOOL VACATION WEEK ACTIVITY CALLED ?SURVIVING THE SEVEN SEAS? WILL BE INTRODUCED. THE MUSEUM'S VIRTUAL PRESENCE WILL BE EXPANDED INVOLVING SUCH ACTIVITIES LIKE BIWEEKLY EDUCATIONAL VIDEO SERIES, VIRTUAL PANEL DISCUSSIONS OF ENSLAVED LABOR, BLACK SAILORS, SHIP DESIGN ACROSS CULTURES, AND CRYPTOLOGY IN NAVAL HISTORY. VIRTUAL JULY 4TH CELEBRATION AND VIRTUAL USS CONSTITUTION 224TH BIRTHDAY PARTY WILL BE HELD. THE MUSEUM WILL PRODUCE MINUTE LONG ARTIFACT VIDEOS TO HIGHLIGHTING THE HUMAN STORIES BEHIND 12 SIGNIFICANT ARTIFACTS FROM ITS COLLECTION. ALL CONTENT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. INTERGENERATIONAL VIRTUAL PROGRAMS LIKE GAME NIGHTS WILL BE HELD. A MONTHLY BLOG WILL EXPLORE RESEARCH INTO EVENTS, PERSONALITIES, AND THEMATIC TOPICS FROM THE SHIP'S HISTORY. THE EDUCATIONAL PORTAL OF THE MUSEUM WILL BE REDESIGNED WITH NEW CIVICS-THEMED SCHOOL PROGRAMS. A NEW VIDEO TOUR OF THE SHIP FOR STUDENTS WILL BE PRODUCED. 12 SHORT INTRODUCTORY VIDEOS ABOUT THE WAR OF 1812 AND LIFE AT SEA WILL BE PRODUCED. THE EDUCATOR RESOURCE PORTAL WILL BE REDESIGNED AND ENABLE TEACHERS TO EASILY ACCESS THESE MATERIAL. A TEACHER ADVISOR PANEL WILL BE INITIATED TO ENSURE THAT THESE RESOURCES MEET THE EDUCATORS? NEEDS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE MAIN OUT COME IS THE RESUMPTION AND EXPANSION OF THE MUSEUM?S ROBUST ACTIVITIES IN A SAFER WAY, ESPECIALLY FOR STUDENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPLY A HANDS ON EXPERIENCE OF THE US NAVAL HISTORY FOR ITS AUDIENCES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE GRANT ARE STUDENTS AND CHILDREN, YOUNG VISITORS OF THE MUSEUM, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES EXPERTS, GENERAL PUBLIC, AND THE MUSEUM STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

FATAL PASSAGE: THE TRANSATLANTIC TRADE IN HUMAN LIVES [THE MARITIME SLAVE TRADE IN NORTH AMERICA BEGINS AND ENDS IN FLORIDA. IT STARTS WITH THE SERVANTS OF THE EARLY CONQUISTADORS AND THE FOUNDING OF ST. AUGUSTINE IN 1565. IT CONTINUES THROUGH THE ABOLITION OF THE MARITIME TRADE IN 1808, TO THE CLANDESTINE VOYAGES THAT CONTINUED TO SUPPLY NORTH AMERICA WITH FORCED LABOR UNTIL SLAVERY ITSELF WAS ABOLISHED IN THE US. THE MUSEUM HAS SHIPWRECK ARTIFACTS SPANNING FROM 1600 THROUGH 1860, ENABLING IT TO PROVIDE HARD EVIDENCE OF ALL PERIODS OF THE TRADE. SINCE 1995, THE MUSEUM HAS TOURED TWO EXHIBITIONS ON THE SLAVE TRADE NATIONALLY BUT WAS NEVER ABLE TO SHOW THE COLLECTION ONSITE DUE TO SPACE RESTRICTIONS. IN 2020, THE MUSEUM BECAME ABLE TO DOUBLE THE SIZE OF ITS PUBLIC AREAS. UNFORTUNATELY, DUE TO THE IMPACT OF COVID ON REVENUE, INSTALLATION RESOURCES DRIED UP. THE REQUEST IS TO SUPPORT A 4,000 SF PERMANENT INSTALLATION, ACCOMPANIED BY A RELATED FREE ONLINE RESOURCE.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE MEL FISHER MARITIME HERITAGE SOCIETY WILL BE USED TO CREATE A PERMANENT EXHIBITION TITLED "FATAL PASSAGE: THE TRANSATLANTIC TRADE IN HUMAN LIVES" AND RELATED PUBLIC ONLINE RESOURCES. THE EXHIBITION WILL FOCUS ON THE MARITIME SLAVE TRADE IN NORTH AMERICA WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF FLORIDA. THE GRANT WILL BE USED TO RETAIN SEVEN EMPLOYEES AND CREATE FOUR ADDITIONAL CONTRACT POSITIONS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;A NEW PERMANENT EXHIBITION WILL FEATURE MAJORITY OF THE MUSEUM?S TRANSATLANTIC SLAVE TRADE COLLECTIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL UTILIZE ITS NEWLY EXPANDED GALLERIES TO ENLARGE THE SLAVE TRADE EXHIBIT FROM 800 TO 4,000 SQUARE FEET. A WALK-THROUGH ENVIRONMENT DEPICTING A SLAVE SHIP?S CAPTIVES? DECK WILL BE BUILT. TWENTY-THREE CUSTOM-MADE, SELF-LIT CASES WILL BE UPDATED WITH NEW LIGHTING. MATCHING AUDIO AND VIDEO MATERIAL WILL BE UPDATED WITH NEW HARDWARE. THE VIRTUAL EXHIBITION OF SLAVE TRADE HOLDINGS LAUNCHED IN 2018 WILL BE EXPANDED WITH ELEMENTS MODIFIED FROM THE ONSITE EXHIBITION. THE EXHIBITION WILL INCLUDE VIDEO INTERVIEWS WITH SCHOLARS, UNDERWATER FOOTAGE OF WRECK SITES, 3D IMAGE OF SELECTED ARTIFACTS, TIMELINES, AND ILLUSTRATIVE MAPS. THE NEW PHYSICAL EXHIBITION WILL BE SUPPLIED WITH OBJECT LABELS BEARING QR CODES TO ENCOURAGE VISITORS TO ACCESS THE ONLINE MODULES USING THEIR SMART PHONES, THEREBY ENHANCING THEIR MUSEUM EXPERIENCE. EXISTING PROGRAM STAFF, INCLUDING THE CHIEF CURATOR, CURATORIAL ASSISTANT AND MARKETING MANAGER AND THREE CONSULTING SCHOLARS WILL BE RE-HIRED.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT IS A LARGER AND BETTER EXHIBITION SPACE, A MORE FULLY STAFFED MUSEUM ON A FULL TIME BASIS, AN ENHANCED AUDIENCE EXPERIENCE, AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE US MARITIME HISTORY OF SLAVERY.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE GRANT ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES EXPERTS IN GENERAL, AND THE MEL FISHER MARITIME HERITAGE SOCIETY STAFF IN PARTICULAR.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

HUMANITIES FOR ALL: EXPANDING LIBRARY SERVICES IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES [ADVANCING UPON ITS ROLE WITHIN THE CITY TO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL SERVICES TO ALL RESIDENTS, THE LIBRARY IS SEEKING FUNDING FROM THE NEH AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN GRANT PROGRAM TO IMPLEMENT THE HUMANITIES FOR ALL: EXPANDING LIBRARY SERVICES IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES PROJECT, THROUGH WHICH THE ENGLEWOOD LIBRARY WILL HIRE STAFF TO IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS IN THREE LANGUAGES FOR LIBRARY PATRONS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE CITY OF ENGLEWOOD WILL BE USED TO IMPLEMENT A HUMANITIES PROGRAM IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES AT THE PUBLIC LIBRARY OF ENGLEWOOD, SERVING THE COMMUNITY'S DIVERSE POPULATION. THE GRANT WILL RETAIN ONE STAFF POSITION AND CREATE FOUR NEW ONES.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE LIBRARY OF ENGLEWOOD WILL INITIATE ITS MULTILINGUAL LEARNING PROGRAM TITLED 'HUMANITIES FOR ALL: EXPANDING LIBRARY SERVICES IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES.' NEWLY HIRED STAFF WILL CONDUCT THE PROGRAM IN SPANISH, KOREAN, AND HEBREW. A MULTILINGUAL SERVICES COORDINATOR WILL BE HIRED TO OVERSEE THE PROGRAM. THREE LANGUAGE SERVICES PRINCIPAL ASSISTANTS WILL BE HIRED TO CONDUCT PROGRAMMING IN THEIR RESPECTED LANGUAGES, SUCH AS STORY TIMES, LECTURES, CONVERSATIONAL GROUPS, AND ESL CLASSES. THE MULTILINGUAL SERVICES COORDINATOR WILL PLAN A LECTURE SERIES ON CULTURAL BACKGROUNDS, AND HOST EXPERTS WILL TEACH THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE DIFFERENT CULTURES LIVING IN ENGLEWOOD.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;FOR THE POPULATION OF ENGLEWOOD RESIDENTS WHO SPEAK LIMITED TO NO ENGLISH, THIS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE SERVICES IN THEIR OWN LANGUAGE. FOR THOSE SEEKING TO LEARN ENGLISH, THIS PROGRAM WILL ASSIST THEM IN THAT EFFORT. ALSO THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE ENGLISH SPEAKERS SEEKING TO LEARN ANOTHER LANGUAGE. THE PROGRAM WILL CREATE CONVERSATIONAL GROUPS, ENCOURAGE INTEREST IN OTHER LANGUAGES AND ENSURE THAT ALL IN THE CITY FEEL WELCOME AND FEEL THEIR BACKGROUND IS RECOGNIZED AND CELEBRATED. THE PROJECT WOULD EXPAND LANGUAGE SERVICES AND OFFER CULTURAL SEMINARS, MEETING AN EXISTING NEED IN THE COMMUNITY AND ADVANCING THE HUMANITIES IN ENGLEWOOD.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE COMMUNITY OF ENGLEWOOD, NEW JERSEY, AND THE PUBLIC LIBRARY OF ENGLEWOOD.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

POCUMTUCK VALLEY VOICES: A HISTORY MUSEUM SHARING ITS COMMUNITY?S UNDER-REPRESENTED STORIES OF AMERICA?S DIVERSE HISTORY [POCUMTUCK VALLEY VOICES IS A SUITE OF FOUR ACTIVITIES THAT INCREASES THE PUBLIC?S UNDERSTANDING OF AMERICAN HISTORY, PARTICULARLY LESSER-KNOWN NATIVE AMERICAN AND AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORIES, TYING CLOSELY WITH THE A MORE PERFECT UNION INITIATIVE: 1) A CROSS-CULTURAL EXHIBIT OF GIFTS GIVEN BY A MOHAWK HUSBAND OF A COLONIST TO HER FAMILY, WHICH PROVIDES A WINDOW INTO LASTING AND COMPLEX RELATIONSHIPS AMONG NATIVES AND COLONISTS; 2) AN EXHIBIT ON ONE OF THE US?S FIRST NATIVE AMERICAN REGISTERED NURSES WHO BECAME AN ACTIVIST; HER LIFE IS A WINDOW INTO NATIVE AMERICAN 20TH C. EXPERIENCES; 3) NEW RESEARCH ON AFRICAN AMERICAN AND AFRO-INDIAN VETERANS OF THE COLONIAL WARS, TO BE SHARED ONLINE AND IN AN EXHIBIT THAT EXPLORES THEIR ROLE IN THE GAINING OF INDEPENDENCE; AND, 4) VIDEO VERSIONS OF IN-PERSON EDUCATION PROGRAMS ON NATIVE AMERICAN, AFRICAN AMERICAN, AND IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCES WILL BE CREATED TO SUPPORT TEACHING DIVERSE HISTORIES. TITLED ?POCUMTUCK VALLEY VOICES? WILL INVOLVE FOUR ACTIVITIES TO ADVANCE THE PUBLIC?S UNDERSTANDING OF THE LESSER-KNOWN NATIVE AMERICAN AND AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORIES. 1) THEY WILL EXPAND AND REINTERPRET MEMORIAL HALL MUSEUM?S EXHIBIT OF AROSEN?S GIFTS TO HAVE MORE VISUAL PROMINENCE AND TO ENGAGE VISITORS IN THE REAL-LIFE STORY OF AROSEN, HIS WIFE, EUNICE, AND THEIR INDIGENOUS AND ENGLISH FAMILIES. 2) THEY WILL INSTALL A NEW EXHIBIT IN THE MUSEUM FOCUSED ON THE LIFE OF SUSIE YELLOWTAIL IN TANDEM WITH AN EXISTING EXHIBIT OF THE NURSING SCHOOL SHE ATTENDED. 3) THEY WILL INCORPORATE AN INTERACTIVE STORYMAP&NBSP;TO FOCUS ON THE EXPERIENCES OF AFRICAN AMERICAN AND NATIVE AMERICAN SOLDIERS IN THE COLONIAL WARS. 4) THEY WILL CREATE VIDEOS ON SUBJECTS SUCH AS THE ROLE OF WOMAN, IMMIGRATION AND DIVERSITY IN LOCAL HISTORY, WHICH WILL BE MADE WITH EDUCATORS AND AVAILABLE ON YOUTUBE AND THEIR EDUCATION WEBSITE AMERICAN CENTURIES.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: TO INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL HISTORY BY EMPHASIZING THE LESSER-KNOWN NATIVE AMERICAN AND AFRICAN AMERICAN PAST OF THE REGION, TO REJUVENATE THE MUSEUM?S OUTREACH CAPACITY.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AND THE POCUMTUCK VALLEY MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION WILL BENEFIT FROM THE GRANT.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

THE RETENTION OF TWO HUMANITIES POSITIONS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING: "STILL I RISE, THE BLACK EXPERIENCE AT REYNOLDA" [REYNOLDA HOUSE SEEKS $78,110 IN FUNDING FOR THE RETENTION OF TWO EXISTING FULL-TIME POSITIONS WHO WILL UNDERTAKE A NEW OUTREACH INITIATIVE INFORMED BY AN ARCHIVAL EXHIBITION, STILL I RISE: THE BLACK EXPERIENCE AT REYNOLDA. THE BLACK ARTISTS FEATURED IN REYNOLDA?S ARCHIVES PERFORMED IN SPACES THAT (MERE DECADES BEFORE) WERE CLOSED TO THEM, UNLESS EMPLOYED BY THE WHITE REYNOLDS FAMILY. MONUMENTAL CONVERSATIONS [NHCC?S MONUMENTAL CONVERSATIONS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE THE ROLE MONUMENTS PLAY IN OUR LIVES AND OUR COMMUNITIES, AND HOW THEY ADVANCE OR INHIBIT CIVIL SOCIETY, RACIAL JUSTICE, AND EQUITY. NHCC STAFF AND CONSULTANTS WILL FOCUS ON THE ONGOING CONTROVERSIES SURROUNDING MONUMENTS TO JUAN DE O?ATE IN NEW MEXICO. NHCC STAFF AND CONSULTANTS WILL HOLD COMMUNITY CONVERSATIONS, WHICH WILL BE RECORDED AND RELEASED AS A DOCUMENTARY ABOUT ONE COMMUNITY?S PROCESS OF ENGAGING WITH HISTORY, SOCIAL JUSTICE, AND RECONCILIATION. O?ATE WAS THE FIRST SPANISH COLONIZER IN INDIGENOUS LANDS NOW KNOWN AS NEW MEXICO. HE AND HIS MEN BROUGHT CATHOLICISM AND THE KINGDOM OF SPAIN TO THE REGION. HE AND HIS MEN ALSO BRUTALLY ATTACKED AND MURDERED INDIGENOUS PEOPLES. SOME NEW MEXICANS, ESPECIALLY INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, CALL FOR THE REMOVAL OF ALL MONUMENTS TO O?ATE BECAUSE OF HIS VIOLENCE AGAINST INDIGENOUS PEOPLES. OTHERS SEE O?ATE MONUMENTS AS A WELCOME REMINDER OF THEIR SPANISH HERITAGE AND THEIR FAMILY HISTORIES.] [PURPOSE:?TO SUPPORT A SERIES OF&NBSP;PROGRAMS ABOUT LOCAL PUBLIC HISTORY AND MONUMENTS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;NHCC WILL PRESENT A SERIES OF SIX PROGRAMS THAT INCLUDE A HISTORIAN?S PRESENTATION FOLLOWED BY FACILITATOR-LED SMALL GROUP CONVERSATIONS. DISCUSSIONS WILL BE GUIDED BY STORYTELLING PROMPTS&NBSP;OFFERED BY MEMBERS OF THE LATINX, HISPANIC, AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES&NBSP;AND FILMED FOR INCLUSION IN A SHORT DOCUMENTARY. THE DOCUMENTARY WILL BE SCREENED AT A FINAL EVENT(S).&NBSP;&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:?&NBSP;CONSTITUENTS OF THE HISPANIC CULTURAL CENTER AND A PARTNERING INDIGENOUS CULTURAL CENTER WILL COME TOGETHER AS ONE COMMUNITY TO CONSIDER&NBSP;FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS ABOUT HISTORICAL MONUMENTS,&NBSP;BUILDING A&NBSP;SHARED COMMITMENT TO TRUTH, HEALING, AND RECONCILIATION.&NBSP;&NBSP; &NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;RESIDENTS OF THE REGION, ESPECIALLY THOSE AFFECTED BY RECENT PROTESTS AND VIOLENCE REGARDING PUBLIC MONUMENTS&NBSP;DEDICATED TO&NBSP;JUAN DE&NBSP;O?ATE.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

NEW STORIES OF THE WEST, FOR THE WEST [THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA PRESS IS ONE OF THE PRE-EMINENT PUBLISHERS OF THE STORY OF THE AMERICAN WEST AND NATIVE NORTH AMERICA, BUT THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS PUT THIS CORE HUMANITIES MISSION IN JEOPARDY WITH REDUCED PRODUCTIVITY FROM ALL STAGES OF BOOK PRODUCTION THREATENING THE VIABILITY OF CRITICAL PRESS STAFFING LINES. AND YET, THE OU PRESS AND ITS ENGAGED PARTNERS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA (THE NEW STORIES OF THE WEST, FOR THE WEST TEAM) ALSO SEE THE OPPORTUNITIES PRESENTED BY THE PANDEMIC TO BOTH SUPPORT THE PRESS AND TO EXPAND THE AUTHORSHIP AND DISSEMINATION OF THE STORY OF THE WEST. AFRICAN AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE FELLOWSHIP AND CIVIL RIGHTS TRAIL [FUNDING FROM NEH WILL SUPPORT A ONE-YEAR, FULL-TIME AFRICAN AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE FELLOWSHIP AT THE CLEVELAND RESTORATION SOCIETY (CRS) FOR AN EMERGING BIPOC PROFESSIONAL. THE FELLOW WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR RESEARCHING, CURATING, AND UPLOADING IN-DEPTH HUMANITIES CONTENT TO THE TRAIL'S DEDICATED WEBSITE; CONDUCTING ORAL HISTORIES WITH ELDERS IN THE COMMUNITY; COORDINATING COMMUNITY EVENTS; AND COMPLETING OTHER TASKS THAT ARE CRITICAL TO PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION.] [PURPOSE:'THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT&NBSP;A ONE-YEAR, FULL-TIME AFRICAN AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE FELLOWSHIP, RESPONSIBLE FOR SPEARHEADING&NBSP;IMPLEMENTATION OF&NBSP;THE CIVIL RIGHTS TRAIL PROJECT.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;DEVELOPMENT OF INTERPRETIVE CONTENT,&NBSP;OHIO HISTORICAL MARKER&NBSP;INSTALLATIONS AND EVENTS,&NBSP;DEVELOPMENT OF A WEBSITE&NBSP;AND MOBILE APP,&NBSP;OUTREACH TO COMMUNITY AND NEIGHBORHOOD RESIDENTS, AND&NBSP;ONGOING SITE SELECTION FOR THE TEN-SITE TRAIL.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:'THE TRAIL&NBSP;AND ITS COMPANION WEBSITE&NBSP;WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CIVIL RIGHTS IN THE NORTH.&NBSP;PARTICIPANTS WILL&NBSP;REFLECT ON&NBSP;STORIES OF STRUGGLE&NBSP;FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS IN CLEVELAND AND&NBSP;ENGAGE WITH ONGOING QUESTIONS OF&NBSP;RACIAL EQUITY AND SOCIAL JUSTICE.&NBSP; &NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;ACADEMICS, COMMUNITY ELDERS,&NBSP;LOCAL&NBSP;HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, NEIGHBORHOOD RESIDENTS,&NBSP;AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:'THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

A REIMAGINED COMMEMORATION: THE CIVIC SEASON, JUNETEENTH - JULY 4TH [AN AID TO OVERSTRETCHED CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS AND A PUBLIC EAGER TO ENGAGE, THE MADE BY US PROJECT, LED OUT OF THE ATLANTA HISTORY CENTER IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OVER 100 HISTORY ORGANIZATIONS NATIONWIDE, CREATES AVENUES TO CONNECT MILLENNIALS AND GEN Z WITH HISTORY AND CIVICS. DESPITE A SMALL TEAM AND FUNDING CONSTRAINTS IMPOSED BY THE CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC, THIS EFFORT HAS EARNED A TRACK RECORD OF CAPACITY-BUILDING, ENGAGING PUBLIC PROGRAMS THAT MEET YOUNG ADULTS WHERE THEY ARE WITH HUMANITIES SCHOLARSHIP AND CONTENT. ONE SUCH EFFORT, THE CIVIC SEASON BETWEEN JUNETEENTH - JULY 4TH, IS WELL POSITIONED FOR SUCCESS AND IMPACT AS WE APPROACH THE 250TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE UNITED STATES, AND FUNDING FROM THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN WOULD ENABLE THIS PROGRAM TO CONTINUE AND GROW IN 2022. CRITICAL PERSPECTIVES&NBSP;FROM BIPOC YOUTH, IMMIGRANTS, AND VETERANS&NBSP;WILL BE INCLUDED THROUGH INTENTIONAL DIALOGUES. HISTORICALLY INFORMED PARTICIPATION IN&NBSP;FUTURE&NBSP;CIVIC SEASONS&NBSP;AND&NBSP;AMERICA?S&NBSP;250TH WILL BE&NBSP;EXPANDED NATIONALLY.&NBSP; &NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;YOUNGER ADULTS FROM THE MILLENNIAL AND GEN Z GENERATIONS, WITH ADDITIONAL OUTREACH PLANNED TO ENGAGE INDIVIDUALS FROM BIPOC COMMUNITIES.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

ILLUSTRATED ESSAY PROJECT USES THE GEOGRAPHICAL LENS OF THE FORMER BOUNDARY LINES OF THE MORRIS AND JUMEL ESTATES (ABOUT 50 BLOCKS OF TODAY?S WASHINGTON HEIGHTS AND HARLEM NEIGHBORHOODS IN MANHATTAN) TO FRAME STORIES FROM THE LAND?S ORIGINAL INHABITANTS, THE LENAPE PEOPLE, MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY, AND TODAY?S DOMINICAN-AMERICAN COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK ALONGSIDE THREE KEY PARTNERS TO DEVELOP A ESSAYS AND AUDIO-VISUAL RESOURCES RELATING TO KEY TOPICS THAT ARE CENTRAL TO TELLING THE STORIES OF THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE AND EVOLUTION OF AMERICA.] [PURPOSE:?PRODUCTION OF A SERIES OF SHORT, ILLUSTRATED ESSAYS AND AUDIO-VISUAL RESOURCES TO CONTEXTUALIZE THE ORIGINAL SITE OF THE MORRIS-JUMEL&NBSP;PROPERTY&NBSP;(FIFTY&NBSP;BLOCKS OF TODAY?S WASHINGTON HEIGHTS AND HARLEM NEIGHBORHOODS IN MANHATTAN)&NBSP;WITHIN AMERICAN HISTORY.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;RESEARCH AND CREATE RESOURCES ABOUT THE&NBSP;DIVERSE&NBSP;PEOPLE WHO LIVED OR CURRENTLY LIVE WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE ORIGINAL 1765 MORRIS-JUMEL&NBSP;MANSION PROPERTY&NBSP;INCLUDING THE LAND?S&NBSP;ORIGINAL&NBSP;INHABITANTS, THE LENAPE PEOPLE, MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY, AND TODAY?S&NBSP;DOMINICAN&NBSP;AMERICAN COMMUNITY.&NBSP;WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LENAPE CENTER, BLACK GOTHAM EXPERIENCE, AND THE DOMINICAN STUDIES INSTITUTE.&NBSP;&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;CREATION OF A SERIES OF ILLUSTRATED ESSAYS&NBSP;AND AUDIO-VISUAL RESOURCES.&NBSP;&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;VISITORS TO THE MORRIS-JUMEL&NBSP;MANSION, WITH EXPANDED OUTREACH TO CURRENT NEIGHBORHOOD RESIDENTS OF WASHINGTON HEIGHTS AND HARLEM.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

FORT MACKINAC READING ROOM AND SCHOOL REINTERPRETATION [THIS PROJECT WILL REINTERPRET THE ORIGINAL 1879 READING ROOM AND SCHOOL BUILDING AT FORT MACKINAC TO BETTER REPRESENT ITS APPEARANCE IN THE 1880S, AND CREATE A NEW EXHIBIT FOCUSED ON THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE IN THE U.S. ARMY OF THE LATE 19TH CENTURY, ARMY REFORMS, AND EDUCATION AT FORT MACKINAC. READING ROOMS AND SCHOOLS SUCH AS THE ONE AT FORT MACKINAC WERE PART OF ARMY-WIDE EFFORTS TO EDUCATE ENLISTED SOLDIERS, NEARLY 50% OF WHOM WERE IMMIGRANTS IN THE POST-CIVIL WAR ERA. AT FORT MACKINAC, SOLDIERS FROM 22 COUNTRIES SERVED BETWEEN 1867 AND 1895. BOMBSHELL [BOMBSHELL (W.T.), IS A PLANNED 90-MINUTE DOCUMENTARY EXPLORING AMERICA?S REACTION TO THE ATOMIC BOMBING OF HIROSHIMA AND ITS LEGACY. BOMBSHELL TRACES HOW THE US GOVERNMENT CONSTRUCTED AN APPEALING NARRATIVE FOR AMERICAN CONSUMPTION, HOW ONE REPORTER?S NON-FICTION MASTERPIECE BLEW APART THAT NARRATIVE, AND HOW WASHINGTON RE-ASSERTED ITS OFFICIAL LINE AND INSTILLED IT IN THE NATIONAL CONSCIENCE. BOMBSHELL INTRODUCES FRESH INSIGHT INTO CLASSIFIED REPORTS, SPEECH DRAFTS, LETTERS AND ARTICLES THAT SOME SAY SHAPED THE OFFICIAL NARRATIVE, AND OTHERS ARGUE EXPOSE THAT NARRATIVE AS GOVERNMENT PROPAGANDA. IT WILL PROBE THE ROLE OF THE BLACK PRESS IN WWII AND HOW IT REACTED TO THE BOMBINGS OF HIROSHIMA AND NAGASAKI THROUGH THE PRISM OF RACE. AND BOMBSHELL UNCOVERS FOR AN AMERICAN AUDIENCE WHAT THE JAPANESE REPORTED IN THE FIRST HOURS AFTER THE ATOMIC STRIKES. BOMBSHELL IS ABOUT THE POWER OF NARRATIVE, PERCEPTION, PUBLIC OPINION AND WHAT WE CONVINCE OURSELVES OURSELVES REGARDLESS OF THE TRUTH.]

AT THE WHITE HOUSE, THE SITUATION ROOM BUZZES WITH ACTIVITY. U.S. INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES ARE CONVINCED THAT SOMALI TERRORISTS HAVE SNUCK INTO THE COUNTRY FROM CANADA ? AND WILL EXPLODE BOMBS ON THE NATIONAL MALL DURING THE INAUGURATION. UNSEEN BY THE AMERICAN PUBLIC, HILLARY CLINTON, CONDOLEEZZA RICE AND THE HIGHEST LEVELS OF THE BUSH AND OBAMA ADMINISTRATIONS ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO ENSURE THAT THE PLOT IS NOT SUCCESSFUL ? AND THAT THE PRESIDENCY WILL SURVIVE IF IT IS. HERE, THE PEOPLE RULE, A TWO-HOUR FILM FOR PBS, WILL UNFOLD AROUND A NUMBER OF BROAD THEMES, EACH INVOLVING SEVERAL TRANSITIONS. WE WILL HEAR INTERESTING AND ENLIGHTENING STORIES OF NOTABLE TRANSITIONS IN HISTORY.]

DIAMOND DIPLOMACY [DIAMOND DIPLOMACY IS AN HOUR-LONG DOCUMENTARY FILM FOR BROADCAST, ABOUT U.S. JAPAN RELATIONS THROUGH A SHARED LOVE OF BASEBALL. TWO EX-BALLPLAYERS, ONE AMERICAN & ONE JAPANESE WILL TELL THEIR OWN BASEBALL STORIES, WHILE KEY POINTS DURING A 150-YEAR HISTORY (STARTING IN 1872) WILL BE HIGHLIGHTED.]

COMING ROUND: THE KASHIA-POMO STRUGGLE FOR HOMELAND [COMING ROUND: THE KASHIA-POMO STRUGGLE FOR HOMELAND (COMING ROUND) IS THE STORY OF A NATIVE CALIFORNIA TRIBE?S REMARKABLY SUCCESSFUL EFFORT TO RECOVER SACRED LAND AND THEIR QUEST FOR REUNIFICATION WITH DESCENDANTS OF FAMILY MEMBERS BROUGHT TO RUSSIA AT THE END OF THAT COUNTRY?S BRIEF COLONIAL VENTURE ON THE CALIFORNIA COAST.]

BOMBSHELL [THIS IS A DEVELOPMENT GRANT REQUEST FOR BOMBSHELL, AN INTENDED 90-MINUTE FEATURE DOCUMENTARY, WILL TRACE HOW THE US GOVERNMENT CONSTRUCTED AN APPEALING NARRATIVE FOR AMERICAN CONSUMPTION, HOW ONE REPORTER?S NON-FICTION MASTERPIECE BLEW APART THAT NARRATIVE, CAUSING NATIONAL SOUL SEARCHING, AND HOW WASHINGTON THEN ENLISTED HOLLYWOOD TO RE-ASSERT ITS OFFICIAL LINE AND INSTILL IT INTO THE NATIONAL CONSCIENCE. ABOVE ALL, BOMBSHELL IS ABOUT THE POWER OF NARRATIVE, PERCEPTION, PUBLIC OPINION, AND WHAT WE CONVINCE OURSELVES REGARDLESS OF THE TRUTH.]

NIHUNAVEA: MY HEART, MY CENTER [NIHUNAVEA IS A FEATURE-LENGTH DOCUMENTARY FILM (CO-DIRECTED BY SANDRA HERNANDEZ AND COLIN ROSEMONT) BEARING WITNESS TO THE COMPLEX STRUGGLES OF RECLAIMING NATIVE CALIFORNIA INDIAN CULTURAL HERITAGE, SPIRITUALITY, AND TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY. SET SHORTLY AFTER THE TEJON INDIAN TRIBE?S DECADES-LONG STRUGGLE FOR SOVEREIGNTY THROUGH FEDERAL REAFFIRMATION, SANDRA HERNANDEZ?AN ENROLLED MEMBER AND ELECTED OFFICIAL OF THE TEJON INDIAN TRIBE?FORGES A PATH THROUGH GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, MUSEUM INSTITUTIONS, & ACADEMIA AS SHE WORKS TO REVITALIZE THE KITANEMUK LANGUAGE, REPATRIATE ARTIFACTS, AND STRENGTHEN THE FOUNDATIONAL CORE OF HER NATIVE IDENTITY: FAMILY & COMMUNITY. THIS IS A STORY OF REASSERTING TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY AND RECLAIMING CULTURAL HERITAGE IN THE FACE OF A HISTORICAL LEGACY OF DISPOSSESSION.]

YOU SHOULD NEVER BLINK [YOU SHOULD NEVER BLINK PRESENTS THE REBELLIOUS LIFE OF NUN, ARTIST, AND EDUCATOR, CORITA KENT, ALSO KNOWN AS SISTER CORITA (1918-1986). FROM A WORKING POOR FAMILY, CORITA HARNESSED HER CREATIVITY AND FAITH TO BUILD A LIFE AS AN ARTIST. BY THE 1960S SHE WAS A CULTURAL ICON, GRACING THE COVER OF NEWSWEEK AND PIONEERING A SOCIALLY-ENGAGED ART PRACTICE. BUT HER CONTRIBUTION IS TOO OFTEN OVERLOOKED, AND SHE IS AT RISK OF BEING FORGOTTEN. COMBINING ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE, INTERVIEWS, AND ANIMATED SEQUENCES THAT WILL BRING NEWLY DIGITIZED PHOTOGRAPHS BY CORITA TO LIFE, THIS DOCUMENTARY REINSERTS THE JOYFUL ART AND ACTIVISM OF CORITA INTO THE NARRATIVE. SHE STILL HAS SO MUCH TO TEACH US.]

THE COLFAX MASSACRE [THIS PROJECT EXPLORES THE HISTORY OF THE 1873 COLFAX MASSACRE, THE SUBSEQUENT SUPREME COURT CASE U.S. VS. CRUIKSHANK AND THEIR EFFECT ON THE POLITICAL RIGHTS OF THE SOUTH?S BLACK POPULATION AND THE ULTIMATE FATE OF RECONSTRUCTION.]

SUN RA FROM SATURN [A DOCUMENTARY FILM ABOUT THE INFLUENTIAL PIANIST AND BANDLEADER SUN RA (N? HERMAN POOLE BLOUNT, 1914-1993). THE SOPHISTICATION AND RANGE OF RA?S MUSIC, HIS CHARISMATIC PERSONALITY, HIS INTELLECTUAL EXPLORATIONS AND WRITINGS, AND HIS CONTINUING IMPACT ON JAZZ AND RELATED GENRES, MAKE RA A GERMINAL FIGURE OF THE 20TH CENTURY.]

CANADA LEE, NATIVE SON [CANADA LEE, NATIVE SON TELLS THE INSPIRING STORY OF ONE OF THE 20TH CENTURY?S GREATEST YET FORGOTTEN HEROES. CANADA WAS A PIONEERING AFRICAN AMERICAN ATHLETE, MUSICIAN, ACTOR, PRODUCER AND ACTIVIST WHO POURED HIS TALENT INTO FIGHTING FOR RACIAL AND ECONOMIC EQUALITY. HIS UNCOMPROMISING STANCE PROMPTED THE U.S. GOVERNMENT TO LABEL HIM A COMMUNIST, DESTROYING HIS REPUTATION AND CAREER. BROKEN-HEARTED AND IMPOVERISHED, LEE DIED AT THE AGE OF 45 FROM KIDNEY DISEASE.]

TEZUKA: GOD OF MANGA [THE PRODUCERS SEEK DEVELOPMENT FUNDING FOR A FEATURE LENGTH (82 MINUTE) DOCUMENTARY EXPLORING THE EXTRAORDINARY LIFE AND CAREER OF OSAMU TEZUKA (1928-1989), KNOWN IN JAPAN AS ?THE GOD OF MANGA.? ONE OF THE WORLD?S MOST PROLIFIC AND INFLUENTIAL STORYTELLERS, HIS WORK IS UNIVERSALLY CREDITED WITH ELEVATING JAPANESE COMICS AND ANIMATION TO THE HEIGHTS OF GLOBAL POPULAR CULTURE, INCLUDING IN THE U.S.]

OUR MR. MATSURA [OUR MR. MATSURA, A FEATURE-LENGTH DOCUMENTARY, WILL TELL THE STORY OF JAPANESE-BORN PHOTOGRAPHER FRANK (SAKAE) MATSURA WHO CAME TO LIVE IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST IN THE EARLY YEARS OF THE 20TH CENTURY. MATSURA CREATED A BODY OF WORK THAT TRANSCENDED MERE DOCUMENTATION OF HIS ADOPTED HOME. HE DEPICTED, WITH OBVIOUS WARMTH AND CONNECTION, THE VARIED PEOPLES OF NORTHEASTERN WASHINGTON STATE, ALONG WITH SURPRISING SELF-PORTRAITURE SOME OF WHICH READS AS PHOTOGRAPHIC ?PERFORMANCE.? IN ADDITION, HE EXTENDED THIS PERFORMANCE PHOTOGRAPHY INTO COLLABORATIVE VISUAL STORYTELLING WITH MEMBERS OF THE DIVERSE POPULATION IN OKANOGAN COUNTY, WHITE SETTLERS AND NATIVE AMERICAN PEOPLE ALIKE. IT IS A UNIQUE PORTFOLIO OF IMAGERY AND HAS MUCH TO TELL US ABOUT A TRANSITIONAL TIME IN U.S. HISTORY.]
